It includes "a uniquely shaped fireball that produces stunning effects behind the armor, inside the target."
Whatever it means, it won't be pleasant.
Eight golden rules for living in a dorm

It's been 11 years since I've moved into the dorms, when I was a 19-year-old who still believed in beanies and moral relativism, but only now do I remember the forced smiles of those I annoyed — and the numerous complaints about others.
Most of what I've learned can be summed up in eight simple rules.
Moving into a dorm may bring on a range of moods ranging from the nervous breakdown to the jitters.

The small talk is tempting: to tell people where you're from, whether and where you've spent a gap year, what you think of Corbyn and that 'to be honest, you don't really care about Marmite because, for real guys, it's just yeast extract HAHAHA I'll be in my room.'
Take a deep breath.
And help others breathe - ask questions and show interest.
They can liven up a conversation and help you differentiate between people you’d like to hang out with and those you wouldn’t talk to even if the flood came and they were the only ones with boats.
Don't suffocate people.
Bedrooms are often the scene of parties with drinking, movie nights, and socializing, but they are also the place where people get dressed and try on underwear.
Related topics: Don't even think about starting college in a relationship
Introverts get special treatment at university.
Your dorm room should be a sanctuary, but in many homes you will find a culture of dorm room wandering, based on friendship, socialization, and life-long friends.
This may be terrible news for someone who is trying to recharge their batteries.
Nothing in this culture allows you to say, "I like you and I want to be friends, however I want you to leave so I can recuperate the energy I spend interacting with you."
Try to pick up on when a colleague is weary of socializing - and try texting instead of knocking on the door.
Come to the point: do it.
A guy who was dorming with me had a policy that said if a door wasn't locked, then he was invited to go in.
He has seen a lot of things.
Make friends by cooking.

As you start uni in Bake-Off fever, if you knock on someone's door to say hi and take a plate of brownie, it seems a bit less weird, a bit less 1950’s, “welcome to the neighbourhood, I baked you something, now smile while I ask personal questions.”
Homemade treats are a great way to make friends.
Your roommates will feel obliged to talk and could end up associating your face with a tasty surprise.
Of course, you have to be a good cook.
The flour, sugar and fat bombs will likely have the rest pretending to be asleep when you knock on the door.
Stealing food is a common crime in college dorms.
So if you steal somebody's chick it is theft, but if you take a drop of milk to put into your tea it is still theft?
Ask the owner.
He will probably tell you to go ahead and eat it even if it's boiling on the inside.

If somebody steals your stuff, it's annoying and I get it - you're still trying to handle the situation more maturely than my dormmate who dyed her milk with liquid dish soap to punish the people who had been stealing.
He is now in jail.
Don't make a noise that doesn't let the others sleep or study.
Not only is it a common sense approach, but it's literally a glass half-full scenario.
A girl in the corridor with me asked her neighbor to turn the music down because it was 3:00 a.m. and she had an exam tomorrow morning.
Their reaction was to turn the music up.

When the music finally stopped at 5am, the girl had the decency to let them have a couple of hours sleep before cranking the music back up to full volume, locking the door and going to her 3-hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future spouse moved in on the same floor?

On the other hand, wouldn't it be extremely awkward if you confused a neighbor with your future husband, dated, broke up, and then had to meet him daily and maybe even watch as he bagged all your mutual friends?
Of course, you can't fight your heart - but if a hot neighbor is definitely not your future husband, at least try to be rational.
The fine line between prank and intimidation is never more delicate than when you realize someone left their keys in an unlocked room.
A successful prank is amusing, but it can turn nasty in a matter of minutes.
Give an amusing and valuable lesson about safety by hiding something – but never, ever mess someone's room with toothpaste and shampoo.
Lock the door and put the keys in a cup of water and put them in the freezer — but don't glue someone's belongings to the ceiling more than twice.
Violinist David Grimal: There were no global tours in Bach's era.
Beethoven, Brahms, Bartok, Enescu were working people, artists and not sales representatives.

French violinist David Grimal is one of the great musicians of our time, known not only as a soloist but also as an initiator of a less-than-ordinary, quite "odd" project as he puts it, Les Dissonances - an orchestra formed of top international soloists and talented musicians, performing a symphonic repertoire without a conductor, which makes it at least a curiosity in the classical music scene.

Les Dissonances was at the Enescu Festival this year with two performances: a Sunday show with founding soloist David Grimal and a Monday show with a solo by cellist Xavier Phillips, featuring works by Enescu.
Both performances, which took place at the Ateneul, showed audiences a different way to interpret classical music.
Les Dissonances appeared on the classical music scene in 2004 as, at the time, the only classical ensemble without a conductor.
The conductor is the most important musician for musicians.
It is true, on the one hand musicians need an education, either to become soloists or to become interpreters in an orchestra, I'm talking about instrumentalists, not composers.
They are designated as “skilled workers”.
They themselves feel that they need a conductor.
On the other side of the scene, the whole musical fetishization is focused on the conductor.
And so, business, the music industry, does their marketing.
So, we're not talking about music anymore.
"So, if you look at this world, you have on the one hand, very qualified workers, which is stupid, and you have an audience that can't hear but must look, which is also stupid," Grimal says.
The violinist says this change in how he played music came as a result of "musical disappointments" in his solo career.
I was like a top athlete who had to make the same gesture in front of the world with different orchestras, to make a lot of money and to make a lot of money for the music industry.
When I was about 30, 10 years ago, I found it very depressing because I could no longer find the creativity or the human fraternity in the system.
So I didn't find any more sense in going down that path.
So I decided to create Les Dissonances.
"The musical world, extremely conservative, did not want such projects" said conductor Ion Marin in the interview with Radio Romania Muzical.
"How do you imagine you can do marketing with a group of musicians where there are no egos?" the artist asks.
David Grimal admits that Les Dissonances is a "luxury", because none of the musicians that make up the orchestra depend on the success of this project to live.

In 10 years of being a band, the lack of a conductor has not proven to be a detriment to the musical act: "Interestingly, the more complex the repertoire, the simpler it seems, because all the musicians are forced to be present in the opera and not just in the role," says Grimal, adding that in Sunday's show "there were 74 conductors on stage."

Grimal said the Enescu Festival is a "very courageous" one for inviting Les Dissonances: "It's a magnificent festival where you have the greatest orchestras in the world playing three times a day, and in the middle of all of these, you have invited this crazy group."
In a temple of orchestral tradition such as the Enescu Festival, there is room and interest for something different, which breaks barriers.

Speaking of Enescu's music, the violinist says he feels the Romanian composer's music so deeply that he didn't feel the need for a special approach when he introduced Enescu's works in his repertoire.
Grimal notes Enescu's music is very instinctive, but that's when we talk about George Enescu and Romanian music, "because there's also a George Enescu who made French music."

Grimal is campaigning to change the way classical musical education is done, saying that "the musical profession as it is organized today has an air of death" and that "the future of music is music itself".
We don’t need to make the world tour 5 times a year if it doesn’t serve anything.
There were no world tours in Bach's time.
Beethoven, Brahms, Bartok, Enescu were people who worked, who were artists, not commercial representatives.
For me, organizing concerts, festivals, tours, album releases, all of this is wonderful, but only if it is done in the service of music.
Otherwise, we are in a system where creativity suffers, is not free anymore.

To illustrate the phenomenon, David Grimal gave the example of Romanian products before and after the accession to the European Union: "In Romania, before entering the EU, you had good vegetables and meat".
You had to adopt sanitary laws to enter the EU, laws that are not good for vegetables and meat.
Food production and agriculture are being drawn into the service of supermarkets, as they are in France.
It's the same with music. It's the same logic.
Les Dissonances face red maybe not very beautiful, but when we cut them they are red true.

In an ideal world, the music should come back to the center and the institutions and industries that manage the system should understand that music doesn't need to be sold, it needs to be shared, and that can start with an educational policy.

"If we were to see - like the Koreans, the Chinese and the Japanese - that Western music is one of the most beautiful things about humanity, we would reintroduce the learning of it in schools, we would reintroduce concerts on TV, and education wouldn't have to go for musical sub-products anymore," says Grimal.
There are certainly things in classical music education that remain very communist, that's everywhere, it's very militarized.
It depends on this discipline whether we compare a musician to a soldier, or whether we form a musician who will play an instrument and will be, first and foremost, a musician.
It's a completely different education, if we want to form a soldier (that education - trans. note) it has to be in a way, if we want to form a musician, it's quite different.
"Who do you think is more dangerous, a soldier or a musician?", the French artist asks with a smile.

Grimal says that for artists, the reward for another way of making music comes from just overcoming this "soldier" status, overcoming what "they believe are their limits": "Musicians discover at a certain point that they are not soldiers, and that is why they come out smiling after a concert."

David Grimal talked about his musical project and about his view of music and of the artist during the third edition of "Ideas Festival", a discussion with the public organized during the George Enescu International Festival by the Aspen Institute Romania.
David Grimal Profile

After studying at the Conservatoire National Superieur de Musique in Paris under Regis Pasquier, a period during which he received guidance and encouragement from such famous artists as Schlomo Mintz and Isaac Stern, David Grimal spent a year studying at the Ecole des Science Politiques in Paris before meeting Philippe Hirshhorn, who changed the course of his life.

David Grimal has an international soloist career, in which he has performed regularly during the past 20 years in some of the most prestigious classical music venues of the world, with renowned orchestras such as the Orchestre de Paris, Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France, Russian National Orchestra, Orchestre National de Lyon, Chamber Orchestra of Europe, Berliner Symphoniker, New Japan Philharmonic, Orchestre de l'Opera de Lyon, Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg, Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, Sinfonia Varsovia, under the baton of conductors like Christoph Eschenbach, Michel Plasson, Michael Schￃnwandt, Peter Csaba, Heinrich Schiff, Lawrence Foster, Emmanuel Krivine, Mikhail Pletnev, Rafael Fruￌhbeck de Burgos, Peter Eotvos, Andris Nelsons, Christian Arming.

He is a recipient of dedications from composers including Marc-Andre Dalbavie, Brice Pauset, Thierry Escaich, Jean-Francois Zygel, Alexander Gasparov, Victor Kissine, Fuminori Tanada, Richard Dubugnon, Ivan Fedele, Philippe Hurel, Anders Hillborg, Oscar Bianchi, Guillaume Connesson and Frederic Verrieres.
Besides his solo career, David Grimal wanted to explore more personal projects.
The freedom granted to him by his collaboration with Les Dissonances has enabled him to develop his inner universe through venturing into repertoires not generally accessible to solo artists.
Alongside Les Dissonances, he founded "L'Autre Saison", a series of concerts performed in aid and alongside homeless people at Saint-Leu, a church in the heart of Paris.
Since 2008, David Grimal has been Artist in Residence at the Opera of Dijon.
She teaches the violin at Musikhochschule in Saarbrücken, Germany.
He also teaches master classes and served on the jury of the Long-Thibaud International Competition in Paris in 2010.
He was awarded the Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres by the French Minister of Culture in 2008.
David Grimal plays a Stradivarius, "ex Roederer" from 1710, and a "Don Quijote", a violin designed for him by the French luthier Jacques Fustier.
David Grimal was present on Sunday in this year's George Enescu International Festival with the Les Dissonances Orchestra, with a program of Debussy, Enescu and Beethoven.
Les Dissonances took the stage again on Monday, this time with cellist Xavier Phillips in the spotlight, and a program of Schnittke, Enescu and Brahms.

Cinema City launches the ultimate challenge for kids: dubbing two characters from Disney's super-production "Frozen 3D"

FedEx Earnings Mixed, Cuts Fiscal 2016 View

FedEx reported disappointing results for the last quarter, with the delivery giant cutting its estimates for annual profits due to weak demand for transport services and higher costs for its ground transport division.
The company also said it plans to hire around 55,000 seasonal workers during the holiday season.
Around the same time last year, FedEx announced it will hire 50,000 seasonal workers for the holiday season.
Shares of the company fell about 2.5% in pre-market trading, about 45 minutes before the opening bell on Wednesday.
FedEx Corp. said it expects to earn between $10.40 and $10.90 for its fiscal year ending in May, down 20 cents, from its earlier estimate.
Analysts were forecasting $10.84 per share, according to a FactSet poll.

The downgraded forecast comes despite average price hikes of 4.9% that took effect on January 4 and higher surcharges for land transport of big or heavy packages, which will be in effect from November.
The company said it still expected higher earnings on the year due to a reduction in costs, higher revenues and the expansion of online trading.
President and CEO Fred Smith said, "The company is facing a considerably weaker economic environment than we previously anticipated, especially in global production and trade."
The hiring plans for the holidays were announced a day after UPS rival FedEx Corp said it planned to hire 90,000-95,000 seasonal workers, about the same number as it hired last year.
In the quarter ended August 31, FedEx earned $692 million, up 6% from the year before.
Earnings per share were $2.42, below the average estimate of $2.44 per share by 12 analysts responding to a Zacks Investment Research survey.
Profits rose 5 percent to $12.3 billion.
Six analysts surveyed by Zacks expected $12.23 billion.
FedEx has been hit in recent years by a decline in international priority shipping, which has led to flat revenues at its Express unit.
But the explosion in online shopping boosted results at the FedEx Ground division.
In the last quarter, ground revenue grew by 29%, but operating income was stagnant due to higher costs for large packages and self-insurance.
The express unit saw an increase in revenues due to higher base rates, while revenues at the freight division fell due to rising costs.
In premarket trading, an hour before the opening bell, FedEx shares fell $3.85, or 2.5%, to $150.15.
They fell 11% this year and 17% from a record high reached on June 11.

In the most highly anticipated meeting in years, Federal Reserve policymakers will gather around a 27-foot Honduran mahogany table for two days this week to decide whether it is time to raise a key interest rate for the first time in nearly a decade.
Over them, at the far end of the Bank’s meeting room, is a mural painting depicting the United States.
The map is intended to remind Janet L. Yellen, the Fed's chairwoman, and her colleagues that they need to put the nation's economic interests above all else.
The Federal Reserve was given a dual mandate by Congress: to maximize employment and maintain price stability in the U.S.
But since the Great Recession, Fed leaders have confirmed that there is one third unwritten charge: financial stability.

And the third factor could be the X factor in a decision that's too difficult to predict, to be announced on Tuesday, that will decide whether the U.S. economy is ready to be weaned off the unprecedented stimulus of near-zero short-term interest rates in place since the end of 2008.

While most of the data points to a strong growing economy, recent turbulence in global financial markets could spook Fed officials already wary of adding volatility by raising the benchmark federal funds rate - even just by a quarter of a percentage point.
"Clearly, the employment and inflation outlook will be the first and foremost,” said Lindsey M. Piegza, chief economist at brokerage Stifel Nicolaus & Co.
"I think, though, if they were looking for an excuse to hold off on raising rates, the rising uncertainty in the global market is enough to give them cause to wait," she said.
There is no consensus regarding what the Fed will do, and the decision itself is provoking market instability.
About half of economists surveyed by Bloomberg recently anticipated a rate increase this week.
But financial markets are expecting the Fed to hold off, with a key indicator showing the probability of a rate hike at only 30%.
That would signal a stock-market drop if the Fed raises rates, unless policymakers soften the blow by promising it will be a long time before the next increase.
On Tuesday, the industrial average Dow Jones gained 228.89 points, or 1.4%, to 16,599.85.
The leap was set off by expectations that Fed policymakers will keep the benchmark interest rate steady this week, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Capital Markets Research Group.
“It would be surprising if the Fed raised rates right now,” Lonski said.
If Fed policymakers did so, “they would have to go deep into their playbook to avoid panicking financial markets."
Other experts said a rate hike would calm financial markets because it would remove uncertainty about when the Fed might act.

Just one month ago, the Federal Reserve seemed poised to raise rates by 0.25 percent this month, the first small step toward a gradual tightening of monetary policy that would confirm the U.S. recovery's strength.
Yellen said in the spring and early summer that she expected a rate increase this year despite the objections of liberals that more economic progress was needed.
While job creation slowed in August, the labor market has grown strongly this year.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.1 percent last month, the lowest in more than seven years and close to the threshold the Federal Reserve considers full employment.
Wage earnings were showing signs of growth.
And although inflation has continued to undershoot the central bank's annual target, Fed policymakers said a key reason was the temporary effect of the sharp drop in oil prices.
The economy "can handle and needs higher rates, given the tight labor market", Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said.
But global markets have become jittery toward the end of this month after China devalued its currency.
The industrial average has fallen 16% below its May record high as investors worried that slowing Chinese growth will drag down world growth.
Stocks have fallen back somewhat this month, with the Dow index now about 10% below its May peak.
The Fed's policy makers have to factor the market turmoil into a complicated calculation of when to raise rates.

"Without what's happened in financial markets and news about weakening Chinese economy, they'd be more firm in the statement," said Stephen D. Oliner, a senior fellow at the UCLA Ziman Center for Real Estate and a former Fed official.
Now, he predicts they will wait at least a month to manage the effects better.
"There's a lot of uncertainty about what the impact will be on the U.S. economy, and there won't be a lot of data to go on after the Chinese events," said Oliner.
Global economic wellbeing is not one of the Fed's primary mandates, so it should be practically inconsequential in decision making.
In fact, the Fed has become the world's monetary authority.
The central bank's influence has been enormous in recent years.
The mere hint in 2013 by then-Fed Chairman Ben S. Bernanke that the Fed might “taper” its monetary expansion set off tremors in markets worldwide.

In a world where markets and economies are increasingly intertwined, it is no wonder that Fed officials not only watch developments abroad but also consult with other central banks and experts to get a better handle on the world economy.
The Fed's decision-making process is "more art than science," said Zachary Karabell, head of global strategy at wealth manager Envestnet Inc.

Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., said this month that “the Fed has a history of overreacting to financial market movements that don't seem to be grounded in underlying economic fundamentals.”
Lacker, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, which decides on interest rate policy, noted the policy moves in 1998-99.

A financial crisis that spread across Asia prompted the Fed to reduce its benchmark rate by 0.75 percent over three meetings "despite limited identification at the time of the implications for U.S. developments," Lacker said.
A year later, Fed officials reversed course.

The Fed should consider financial stability only as a secondary issue unless there is a major crisis such as the 2008 market meltdown, said Adam S. Posen, a former rate-setting member of the Bank of England.
The latest turmoil does not come close to that level, he said.
"We don't want to be in a position of having to worry about a rise in interest rates because the markets get upset," said Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The Federal Reserve Act still has a dual mandate and does not mention financial stability and, until that changes, I don't think it should take premature action.
Looking for an amazing market with a Thai flair?
Try LAX-C in Chinatown.
Yes, Chinatown
The market opened in 1997 is owned by LAX-C Inc.
Often called Thailand’s Costco, LAX-C is a Thai wholesale market that also sells to the public.
Yes, it's in Chinatown and not in Thai Town.

The market/depot is a full-service store that offers a stunning array of fresh, frozen and dehydrated products, popular Thai and Asian snacks and kitchenware, furniture, religious and festival decorations.
There is also an auto parts district where you can buy some motor oil.
The shop is huge and one needs at least an hour to go through all the aisles.
If you get hungry from all that shopping, check out LAX-C BBQ Express.
The store's inner food court (good and cheap) is near the checkout lines and offers a variety of takeout options.
What have in stock: you need something - anything- Thai?
Probably at LAX-C.
Their products are reasonably priced and certain items are sold in bulk.
Fresh products include herbs, fruits and other Asian and Thai products.
The meat section is large, as is the fish section - the servers will clean and fillet the fish and even cook it for you if you like.

A large section of the store is dedicated to a huge freezer aisle, where you can find frozen curry leaves, melon, and ginger, whole ducks, fish, blood and beef tripe, pork bones, fish balls, traditional sausages, semi-prepared meals, and much more.

Wide aisles accommodate shopping carts and forklifts.
Discovery: Fresh durian fruit right in the area of the houses.

Although the store is often crowded, parking is usually easy to find.

4 people have been killed after police in Nepal fired rubber bullets at protesters

Four people, including a 4-year-old boy, have been killed in southern Nepal after police fired rubber bullets at protesters demonstrating against the country's proposed new constitution, an official said Wednesday.
Violence erupted Tuesday evening in the Rupandehi district, about 280 kilometers west of the capital, Kathmandu.
According to Bishnu Prasad Dhakal, the district police chief, more than 1,000 protestors had gathered in front of a police station and some of them threw stones and petrol bombs.
Mr. Dhakal said police first used tear gas and fired warning shots into the air before using rubber bullets.
He said 20 police officers and five civilians were wounded.
It was not immediately clear why the rubber bullets, which are known to kill but are usually used as a less lethal alternative, caused so many deaths.

The clash was the latest incident in weeks of violent protests in Nepal's southern region, where members of the Madhesi ethnic group say the new provinces created under the new constitution would dilute their political influence.
Protests were also held in western Nepal where the Tharu ethnic group is demanding its own state.
At least 40 people, including 11 police officers, were killed in the violent clashes that erupted on August 10.

when four major political parties signed an agreement to split the country into provinces - a major step toward a new constitution but a hugely controversial issue in Nepal, a country ruled centrally for hundreds of years.
The process of drafting a new constitution was started in 2008, but legislators accelerated the process after a devastating earthquake that killed thousands in April.
Lawmakers in Kathmandu this week voted on the draft constitution's provisions and officials said the new charter could be adopted Sunday.

Weight-Loss Surgery May Help Lightly Obese Diabetics
The benefits of weight-loss surgery in people with mild obesity and type 2 diabetes may be maintained for at least five years, according to a new study.
It is still too early to say whether mildly obese diabetics live longer after weight-loss surgery than those who stick with non-surgical treatment.
"It takes a long time to centralize the mortality data," said Dr. Robin Blackstone, a bariatric surgeon who wrote an accompanying commentary in JAMA Surgery.
Weight-loss surgery, sometimes called bariatric surgery, uses different techniques to shrink the stomach.
They suppress the appetite and limit the body's ability to absorb food.
Over the years, bariatric surgery has proved effective in treating Type 2 diabetes, but most studies have involved people with morbid obesity, a body mass index of 35 or higher.
BMI, a measure of weight in relation to height, is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9.
A BMI of at least 25 indicates a person is overweight while people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese.

You can calculate your BMI at: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv.
## 2. U.S. Vetoes U.N. Security Council Resolution Against Settlement Activity

For the new study, researchers from the Min-Sheng General Hospital in Taiwan used data gathered after 2007 in a trial that compared two types of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy - in the medical treatment of type 2 diabetes in people with mild obesity.
The mean BMI of the people who had surgery decreased from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of the study.
In the meantime, the IMC of people who got non-surgical treatments for diabetes stayed almost the same, at 29.
Of those who had the surgery, 36 per cent were completely cured of diabetes and 28 per cent had partial remission.
In the medically treated group, by contrast, diabetes was completely cured in only 1 percent and partially cured in only 2 percent.
In addition, blood pressure, triglycerides and "bad" LDL cholesterol "were generally better in the surgical group," the authors concluded.
Researchers also monitored the participants' blood hemoglobin A1c levels, which reflect average blood sugar levels over time.
Researchers write that the optimal hemoglobin A1c level is below 7%.
After the surgery, their average hemoglobin A1c levels dropped from about 9% to about 6%.
But in the group treated with the medical cocktail, it remained around 8 percent.
But this improved "glycemic control" - reflected by improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce the five-year death rate, lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu, and colleagues, reported.
The research team also compared the average outcomes associated with the two types of surgery.

At 5 years, the gastric bypass group had lost more weight than did the sleeve gastrectomy group (18.7 vs 14.2 kg), had greater reductions in BMI (7.4 vs 5.1), had greater reductions in hemoglobin A1c (3.1 vs 2.1 percentage points), and had a higher probability of complete remission of diabetes (46.9% vs 16.7%).

While the new study does not show a benefit in survival or surgery after five years, there is evidence from a similar study in Sweden of people with a high body mass index that surgery does prolong life, Blackstone of the University of Arizona College of Medicine – Phoenix says.
In the Swedish study, obese people who had bariatric surgery had about a 29 percent lower risk of dying after 15 years compared to a group that tried more conventional methods.
While the new study did not show a survival benefit for patients who had surgery, Blackstone said it is an upbeat outcome for people with BMIs under 35 who are considering the procedure.
“This is the point where this work is critical because it says this surgical intervention is safe in the lower BMI group” without increasing the risk of death or kidney disease, she says.
Blackstone added that patients and their doctors should start taking weight seriously when a patient's BMI reaches 27-30.
“I think we wait way too long to urge people to take this seriously,” she said.
I think that once they accumulate these genetic changes that short-circuit their bodies and make them prone to obesity and diabetes, it's extremely difficult to reverse it.
“Everybody cannot come to Europe” - Dalai Lama - RT news

After 9/11, I wrote to President Bush and expressed my condolences and told him to resolve the issue without resorting to violence.

The number of children who have swallowed hand-washing detergent has quadrupled in the past four years.

According to the Georgia Poison Center, poison control centers across the United States have reported a nearly 400 percent increase since 2010 in the number of children under the age of 12 who have swallowed hand-sanitizer containing high levels of alcohol.

According to Dr. Gaylord Lopez, director of Georgia's Poison Control Center, cases of children under age 12 ingesting hand soap reported to poison centers have soared from 3,266 in 2010 to 16,117 in 2014.
"Kids have access to these products more frequently, and unfortunately a percentage of them end up in the emergency room," Lopez told CNN.
Lopez said some kids deliberately drink detergent to impress their friends or to respond to challenges on social media.
YouTube videos capture teenagers drinking detergent to create cheap drinks.
It seems that teenagers mixed the detergent with mouthwash containing alcohol in order to obtain a stronger drink.
Younger children may be attracted by the attractive smell of laundry detergent.
„A kid does not think that he is doing harm,” Lopez said.
Many of the most desirable types (of hand soap) are those that are scented.
Strawberry, grape and orange-scented hand soaps are the most attractive to children.
Hand sanitizer contains about 45-95% alcohol.
Just a few swallows can poison a small child.
“It’s very concentrated alcohol,” Dr. Stephen Thornton, medical director of the Poison Control Center at the University of Kansas Hospital, told Kansas City’s Fox 4.

Hewlett-Packard will lay off 30,000
Hewlett-Packard Co. is planning to cut between 25,000 and 30,000 jobs as part of the company's restructuring and cost-cutting efforts in the services sector.
HP announced this year that it will split into two publicly traded companies, separating its computing and printing business from its faster-growing corporate hardware and services operations.
The layoffs will result in $2.7 billion in costs beginning in the fourth quarter, the company said.

"These restructuring actions will take HPE to a new level of agility and efficiency – enabling us to invest in key areas of the business and accelerate innovation", said HP CEO Meg Whitman, who will lead the spinoff.

"Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than HP is today, with a broad portfolio of businesses that will provide the foundation for the next generation of enterprise computing," Whitman said.
As a standalone company, we are better positioned than ever to meet the growing demands of our global customers.

It was founded in 1930 by Stanford University graduates Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard, who started out producing electrical equipment in a garage in Palo Alto, which came to be known as the “cradle of Silicon Valley”.
HP is undergoing a massive reorganization to adapt to the shift from traditional computers to mobile devices.

HP, the world's second largest maker of personal computers and one of the biggest technology companies in the United States, announced the latest in a string of recent splits, saying the move was based on the idea that companies perform better when they concentrate on a smaller number of priorities.
FriendsFest:  The comedy show that taught us important lessons about male friendship
The lack of similar characters in TV shows is evident, given that the need for men to open up is now more desperate than ever, with suicide rates among young men at a 15-year high.
In the UK, suicide is the leading cause of death among men aged 20-45, and remains three times more prevalent in men than women.
The Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM) has designated 2015 as the Year of the Man in an effort to challenge the culture that prevents men from seeking help when they need it.
Friendship is the center of this challenge.

A recent study of more than 2,000 high school students who showed signs of depression found that if the patient was surrounded by enough friends "with a healthy mood", their chances of recovery doubled.
Similarly, for people not depressed, a circle of mentally healthy friends halves the odds of developing mental disorders.
Of course, for friendship to work, it must be available in the first place.
In this era of social media-dominated communications, where style often takes precedence over substance, the instantaneity of response often takes precedence over meaningful contact.
Our digital lives have doubled the need to create the appearance of a strong, fun-loving, successful personality, even when isolation is the reality.

This superficial success is dominated by what psychologists call extrinsic values; money, image, social status, all at the cost of intrinsic values - our inner desire for personal growth and friendship - which more deeply affect our mental health.
Billionaire video game maker says, money doesn't buy happiness.
The beauty of the show Friends was that it drew attention to this idea.
Characters were defined by their personalities, which they showed by interacting as friends.

Joey and Chandler's frequent bromance, the times they sit down to watch football in their comfy armchairs, and Ross's passion for Rachel, all come from the fact that men can relate to this situation, even if they often shy away from exploring their feelings fully.
As one social worker explained: "...my role of listening to suicidal and depressed people showed how even the smallest of social interactions can make a difference."
Often, the people who call us don't feel able to talk to friends.
The old axiom to pull yourself up by your bootstraps is strong, as is the feeling of being perceived as weak if you speak openly about difficulties.
Friends is one of the shows that comes to mind when I try to provide more long-term psychological coping mechanisms.
The series highlighted the small moments of friendship among men.
However much outside, objective help is available via the phone, long-term support will have to come from family and close friends.
So, if you're attending Comedy Central's FriendsFest this weekend, which features a fully-restored set for the occasion, why not invite your friends for a coffee at Central Perk.
Or, even better, if you see someone alone in Starbucks, smile and say hello.
You never know what difference your friendship could make.
Friends is being shown, from start to finish - all 236 episodes - by Comedy Central for #FriendsFest

Xi urges more extensive global economic expansion
President Xi Jinping told a group charged with reforming the economy that it must open wider to the world to feed growth.
“China must commit itself to attracting foreign investment and expertise, and improve its opening-up policies,” Xi said at the 16th meeting of the Central Leading Group for Deepening Overall Reform.
Promoting openness and encouraging reforms will give new impetus and vitality and provide impetus for economic growth, Xi said.

The leadership group adopted a number of guidelines, including a negative list of market access regulation, relaxing customs policies, encouraging state-owned enterprises to absorb private capital and reorganizing the system of resident registration.
A negative list will be drawn up, identifying sectors and fields of activity where the investment is not allowed.
The system will be tested incrementally and improved through test programs.
The statement said the measures are important because they give the market a greater role in resource allocation, ensure a business environment based on law, and provide broader market opening.
The state will also reduce controls over the powers delegated to companies, ensuring that companies decide how to conduct their business.
China will also allow its border regions to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms to drive regional growth, the statement said.
In an attempt to open up state-controlled sectors, more sectors will be opened to private investment.

"The state authorities will not change their policy towards foreign investment and will protect legitimate interests of foreign-invested companies and provide them with better services," according to the statement.
In addition, it will be easier for foreign nationals to apply for permanent residence permits or so-called “green cards” by streamlining the requirements and expediting the application process.

The government's proposal today did not satisfy us, otherwise we would not have come to the situation of calling our federations.
The 10 percent we were promised today represents less than we expected.

"Actually, those 10 percent are the money that we have stipulated in our agreement with the Government, since last year, for 2016", said Anton Hadar, the president of Alma Mater, at the end of the discussions.
Ponta: In the future health and education will be the fields where we shall invest all our money

According to him, on Thursday there will be a meeting of FSLI in which will participate representatives of the Government to present to representatives of the trade unions in the country the proposal for a salary increase, and the trade unionists will decide whether to accept the Government's offer.
The premier also told unionists that the government tried to send the draft Salary Law as soon as possible to Parliament so that it can enter into force on December 1.
The draft law foresees a 25% increase in teachers' wages from the total increase of 70%, the increase being phased in over the next four years.
Victor Ponta also promised the unionists that all of the court fines would be paid off in 2016.
Migrant Crisis: Tragedy in the Aegean Sea
At least 22 migrants drowned Tuesday in Turkish territorial waters after a boat carrying them sank.
Among the victims were 11 women and 5 children, AFP reports via Yahoo News.
The boat was in the Aegean Sea and was heading for the Greek island of Kos.
Turkey's coast guard said it rescued 249 people who were on board the boat when it sank and there were no details yet on the boat's nationality.
Two more people died Monday as they attempted to cross the Aegean Sea.
Also over the weekend, 34 immigrants, including four infants and 11 children, drowned off the Greek island of Farmakonisi, located 15 kilometers from the Turkish coast.
The situation was similar: the boat was carrying more people than it could hold, so it sank.
The route has become popular in recent times for migrants trying to escape the war and hardship in countries like Syria and Iraq.
Over 100 stewardesses, fired for being too fat
Air India plans to fire about 130 flight attendants for being overweight, the company announced last week.

The state-owned company said the decision was made for security and recent government regulation purposes, but critics say the measure is “ridiculous” and “shockingly sexist,” according to The Washington Post.
The mass firing is the latest in a decade-long battle between the company and its heavier flight attendants.
The weight limit for flight attendants dates back to the 1980s, when Air India started using charts with the ideal height and weight.
In 2006, Air India fired nine stewardesses who were "exceptionally overweight" because their weight "can affect reflexes and may hinder agility required to carry out emergency procedures."
The flight attendants sued, won, and were rehired, but the company fired them again in 2009.
"All attempts to get them to slim down have failed," a spokesman for the company said at the time.
A Steaua footballer teaches Becali a lesson: What he chose to do
A Steaua soccer player is giving lessons to Gigi Becali about promoting young players.
While the financier of the champions decided to shut down the football academy where he had invested a considerable amount, defender Paul Papp opened a football school.
The "Paul Papp" Academy will operate in the city of Dej, locals being invited to a first selection action.
I'm very happy that we've reached this stage, to start the football academy that bears my name.
For me, it is extremely important to find talented children who can play football without having to worry about material problems at the training sessions.
Their only worry should be how to play football better.
The technical details are not their concern.
They have to make their talent stand out.
This is what the Paul Papp Football Academy wants to do.
"I am waiting for the Mayor Costan Morar as well, at the first selection of the children, in order to show that he is with them", said the football player Papp for the dejeanul.ro.
The Steaua football school is waiting for children aged up to 11 years.
The party wants to govern.
The interim PSD President Liviu Dragnea declared on Tuesday that the entire party wishes to remain in power, and, if the Prime Minister wants, this decision will be formalized at the PSD Congress.
I understand that Mr. Ponta is waiting for this decision from the PSD Congress, everyone wants to govern, the whole party.
If it is to be formalized by a congressional decree, we will do so.
There is no doubt about that.

"There are no elements, voices within the party that would give someone uncertainty about governing, or give someone the impression that someone in the party does not want PSD to remain in government, in the current government, with the current prime minister," Dragnea said at the end of the Permanent National Bureau of PSD.
PSD sets date for congress - what will be decided then

Prime Minister Victor Ponta said on Tuesday that, at the Social Democratic Party Congress, it is important to send a clear message besides electing the Party leadership, i.e. if they want to continue ruling or they want to move to the Opposition.
Dragnea: I will announce Monday if I will run for a role in Congress
On the other hand, Liviu Dragnea will announce next Monday whether he will run for a leadership position in the future Congress.

I will weigh, on Monday, after the Executive Committee, if the Congress date is also established.
            
Q: Aseara, Liviu Dragnea a spus, în cadrul unui interviu, ca vrea sa fie la guvernare în perioada urmatoare, adaugând ca PSD va fi la guvernare în urmatorii patru ani.
A: Last night, Liviu Dragnea said, in an interview, that he wants to be in power in the next period, adding that PSD will be in power in the next four years.
"I will announce if I will run for a leadership position", Dragnea said at the end of the Tuesday meeting of the PSD's National Permanent Bureau.
Asked whether his hesitation about announcing his candidacy is related to the case, Dragnea said he had no such problem.

I have no problem with what you're saying, but I think it's right and honest to tell my party colleagues whether or not I'm going to run as a candidate when the date for the Congress is formally established.
"That's the only rationale", Dragnea said.

The overwhelming majority of social-democrats organizations have proposed the PSD's extraordinary congress on October 11, while the exact date of the congress will be decided on Monday by the party's Executive Committee.
Career Fair Offers Thousands of Jobs at 200 Companies
200 companies are expected at the autumn edition of Career Fair (TdC), an event that will take place in Brasov, Chisinau, Cluj-Napoca, Iasi, Sibiu and Tirgu-Mures.
The companies have several thousand job vacancies, internship opportunities and traineeships, and some of them have already been announced on the official website www.targuldecariere.ro.
Recruiting becoming a bigger priority for companies

According to the statistics gathered during the 100 editions of the Career Fair so far, most companies are interested, besides the actual recruitment, to develop a strong employer brand among young people: 97% of their representatives said they wanted to return to the future editions, while 94% declared that they recommend TdC as a recruitment and employer branding solution.
There are also cases where companies choose to make the hiring in batches, so that they can think more organized about their recruitment.

Those who will be ticking off the attendance list at the TdC in October and November 2015 include Arvato Bertelsmann, Bombardier, Bosch, CIE Matricon, Competence Call Center, DB Schenker, Delphi, Office Depot, Preh, Renault, Schaeffler, Stefanini and Sykes.
Profile of the TdC Candidate
The majority of TdC participants looking for a job are students (59.70%), followed by university graduates (23.05%) and graduates of a master's programme (10.38%).
The least likely to be married are those with a Ph.D. - 0.67% - and those who have a high school diploma or less - 6.20%.

As for their areas of specialisation, most work in IT and Software, the financial and banking sector or insurance, or in marketing, advertising and media or in the automotive and construction industries.
It is no longer news that the IT sector is on a continuous rise in the country.
As a result, there will be a new edition of the Career Fair in IT this year, a niche event dedicated exclusively to IT enthusiasts and professionals.

The 7th edition of the event will bring together business giants such as Accenture, Endava, KFC, McDonald's, msg systems, Siemens, Steelcase, Unicredit Business Integrated Solutions, and Yardi Systems.
Careers Fair, 100th edition
Founded in Cluj-Napoca in 2006, Career Days is today the largest career events network in Romania and Moldova.

The fall edition will take place in Chisinau (Casa Armatei, October 2-3), Iasi (Palas, 6-7 October), Brasov (Casa Armatei, October 14-15), Cluj Global (Sala Polivalenta, October 20-21), Cluj IT (Sala Polivalenta, October 22-23), Sibiu (Business Center, October 28-29) and Targu-Mures (National Theater, November 5).
Details about the companies already registered, as well as about the Career Fair can be found on www.targuldecariere.ro.
An Italian man was caught at the Bors border crossing with immigrants hidden in a truck
Two Sri Lankan citizens were detected on Monday at the Bors border checkpoint while trying to illegally cross the border, hidden in the semi-trailer of a truck driven by an Italian citizen.
Following the investigations, the two were arrested as they were suspected of having paid the driver 4.000 euros to transport them to France, the Border Police announced.
During the routine check, border police noticed a large travel bag, in which they found personal belongings of several persons, prompting them to proceed to a thorough search of the vehicle.
On this occasion, border guards discovered two men hidden in the trailer of a truck among the plastic crates.
The checks revealed that the persons concerned, two men aged 28, are citizens of Sri Lanka and asylum seekers in Romania.

"During the investigations, the young people said they intended to go to France, which is why they contacted a conational, through whom they met with the Italian driver, who offered to take them to the destination, where they were to receive 2,000 euros per person," the Border Police said in a statement.
The two migrants were charged with "attempted fraudulently crossing the state border".

Also, on the road E60, the border policemen from the Oradea Border Police Sector have detained, for 24 hours, an Italian citizen, 45 years old, who was driving a truck, brand Renault Magnum, registered in Romania, that transported cases of plastic for a company from Italy, being presented to the Oradea Court, with a proposal for preventive arrest.
How Satisfied Romanians are in their Couple: Men vs. Women
Most Romanians satisfied with their relationships
That is the conclusion of a study on the occasion of the visit to Romania of John Gray, the famous author of the bestseller "Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus".
A total of 62 percent of respondents said they were "very satisfied" or "satisfied" with the quality of their relationship.

"However, 18% said they were either 'slightly unsatisfied' or 'very unsatisfied' in their relationship, while another 18% said they were 'good'," the study found, according to a press release sent to Ziare.com Tuesday.
The situation is somewhat different when men's and women's answers are analyzed separately.
So, 28 percent of men are very satisfied, 39 percent satisfied, 17 percent about right, 6 percent very dissatisfied and 8 percent dissatisfied.

As for women, 33% stated that they were satisfied, 24% stated that they were very satisfied, 8% stated that they were very unsatisfied, 14% stated that they were slightly unsatisfied and 19% chose the "best fit" category.
When we look at the level of satisfaction (positive), we will observe that men are more satisfied.
As for the neutral state (it's OK), we see a two percent difference.
"Even in the very unsatisfied situation, the difference is greater, in the slightly unsatisfied response, where we see a difference of 6 percent," the statement said.
The study also showed a quarter of Romanian couples (26%) spend an hour or even less time together, 18% spend between five and eight hours together and 45% spend between two and four hours.

The study authors also said that "Romanians feel the need for a little more adventure in their lives (24%), followed by affection (21%), money (21%), security (20%), new (19%), sex (19%), respect (18%), confidence (17%), pleasure (17%), connection (17%), knowledge (16%), protection (14%), importance (14%), learning (12%), freedom (11%), self-knowledge (10%) and control (7%)."
The study was carried out by Extreme Training between June 1 and September 1 on 1,369 people, with a margin of error of 2.6 percent.
Europe once again embarrassed

German Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel said on Tuesday Europe had "made a fool of itself" after the failure of a meeting of EU interior ministers in Brussels on Monday to agree on a plan to distribute asylum seekers across the European Union.
"Europe has again made itself a laughing stock last night," Sigmar Gabriel said at a press conference, where he also serves as Economy Minister in Chancellor Angela Merkel's government, AFP reported.
Earlier, Germany's Interior Minister, Thomas de Maiziere, suggested reducing the EU's structural funds in the case of countries that reject refugee quotas.

European interior ministers, who met in emergency session Monday in Brussels, have failed to reach an agreement on the mandatory redistribution of 120,000 refugees, which the European Commission requested last week to deal with one of the worst migrant crisis in Europe since 1945.
He was mayor just half an hour
The interim mayor of Constanta County's Tuzla commune enjoyed being in office only half an hour, due to the DNA prosecutors.
Taner Resit was appointed as the mayor of the locality, replacing former mayor, Constantin Micu, sentenced for embezzlement, B1 TV informs.
The county prefect, Ion Constantin, was waiting for him at the headquarters of the institution to make the official announcement at 16.00, but he did not arrive anymore.
Why?
Taner Resit was summoned to appear at the DNA Constanta headquarters at 2.00 pm.
After nearly two and a half hours of hearings, he was taken into custody for 24 hours.
Consequently, he was mayor for only 30 minutes.
Prosecutors say he is accused of extorting a businessman from August 16 to September 8, in complicity with Stefan Radu, a businessman who wanted to obtain 48,000 euros from him, Adevarul reported.
The two men threatened the manager, drove away customers, prevented them from entering the store, changed the locks and sequestered the company's goods.
On September 8, Stefan Radu would have hit the administrator in the presence of the vice-mayor.
Thousands of people came to lay candles

Thousands of people have passed by the casket with the lifeless body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor, more people being at St. George Church than at the consecration of the church or at the Great Feast of St. Nicholas, said on Wednesday the priest Emil Caramizaru.
Hundreds of people of all ages are lining up, stretching from the entrance of the church to the side streets, to pass by the catafalque bearing the lifeless body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor.
People waited for about an hour for admission to St. George's New Church, where groups of 40 at a time were allowed inside.
Around 300 people per hour have passed over the coffin of Corneliu Vadim Tudor on Wednesday.

Thousands of people from Bucharest, but also from Cluj, Baia Mare, Iasi, Constanta and Craiova, came, as of Tuesday night, to pay a tribute to Corneliu Vadim Tudor, as many people as we only had at the 300-year-old church reconsecration and at the Great Holiday of Saint Nicholas.

"Corneliu Vadim Tudor attended the 300-year-old church re-sanctification and he sat next to the Holy Synod members, Patriarch Daniel and representatives of the five patriarchs who participated in the re-sanctification", said the parish priest of the church in the Capital, Emil Caramizaru.
According to him, people came with flowers and candles in hand, patiently waiting in line, as if it were some sort of religious holiday.
It's extraordinary behavior from these people, standing perfectly quiet, dignified, children, the old, people on crutches, like they were at a great religious celebration.
“It is touching to see them waiting to pay their final homage to Vadim Tudor,” parish priest Emil Caramizaru added.
The church will remain open all night, as requested by Corneliu Vadim Tudor's family, the priest said, adding that the church was closed at 1 AM and reopened at 7 AM.

He said that on Thursday morning at 10.00, at the Saint George Church, at kilometer 0, a short service will be officiated at, after which the coffin with the body of Vadim Tudor will be transported to the civil cemetery Ghencea, where the burial service will take place, and a religious and military ceremony will be officiated at.

The parish priest said that Vadim Tudor used to come to the church, especially in the evenings after 8 p.m., and asked him to open the reliquary containing the relics of St. Nicholas and prayed in front of it for several minutes.
He used to come here very often, usually in the evening after 20.00, and he’d ask me to open the glass case with the relics of Saint Nicholas and pray.
He said it was a great blessing this church of Brancoveanu's.
He would say: "Think of all the people who have been here: Brâncoveanu, Eminescu, Mihai Viteazul, who put his hand on Saint Nicholas's shoulder."

"'You can imagine how great a blessing this is for this country,' Vadim told me," the parish priest said.
 
Q: "'Preotul a fost un ministru al lui Dumnezeu, el ne-a ajutat chiar si cand am fost in inchisoare', a declarat Vadim, in timp ce credinciosii se imbratisau si se sarutau, unii dintre ei plangand lacrimi de bucurie.
A: "'The priest was a minister of God, he helped us even when we were in prison,' Vadim said, as the faithful embraced and kissed each other, some of them crying tears of happiness.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor will be buried on Thursday at the Ghencea Civil Cemetery, with military honors.
The Senate leadership rejected Tuesday the request of Corneliu Vadim Tudor's widow for the former senator's coffin to be laid in the Senate's lobby.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor was born on 28 November 1949, in Bucharest, he was a writer, politician and journalist.
He founded the Greater Romania Party, was a member of the European Parliament and a former senator.
What's Happening With Darren Cahill
Simona Halep faces a crucial decision for her career, being forced to choose whether to continue or not to collaborate with the coach Darren Cahill.
The two have worked together this season in Adidas Player Development, with the Australian only traveling to the bigger tournaments with the Romanian.
Simona had only praise for Cahill, who seems to be the only coach who could assert himself in front of the whimsical athlete.
But, at the end of the year, the Adidas program will end and Halep will have to decide if she will offer a substantial contract to Cahill or break off the collaboration.
We don't know exactly what will happen yet.
We'll see.
"After Singapore I will be able to give an answer", Simona said at a press conference.
Darren Cahill is one of the most expensive tennis coaches, he asking for a contract of around one million dollars per year.
He is also a sports commentator, a profession he doesn't want to quit at the moment.
Simona Halep and Darren Cahill will work together for the last time at next week's WTA Finals in Singapore.
It wasn't normal, I wasn't respected
Victor Piturca revealed how he parted ways with the Romanian national team last fall.
Former coach confesses that he didn't get along with the president of the Romanian Football Federation, Razvan Burleanu, after he replaced Mircea Sandu, and thus took the decision to leave the team.
He finally offered the president of the Federation a substantial pay raise to stay, but was turned down.
I don't regret leaving the national team.
I was sorry then, because I was leaving a job behind.
That's what I thought then was right for me and I think it was right for me.
What happened to me as a coach was not normal, I wasn't respected, my work wasn't respected.

I worked well with the people at the federation before, but when Burleanu came at the federation he came with a preconceived idea, he didn't know me, he heard different opinions about me from the press.
It hasn't changed me because it was very difficult in that moment, with the results we had and the financial situation involved.
We continued working, we’ve had a great time and he probably changed his mind.
But I wanted to leave.
If they wanted me to stay, I offered them a contract extension.
We have around 400 000 euros per year, the next one was to have around 600 000.
I have not discussed with Burleanu, but with his right-hand.
"He agreed, but only if we finish in first place in the group", Piturca told Dolce Sport.
Victor Piturca resigned from the Romanian national team in the fall of last year, despite the team's good results in the preliminaries of Euro 2016.
The technician accepted the offer to train in Saudi Arabia, he immediately taking over the Al Ittihad group.
Tanks and Water Cannons at the Border

Hungarian police have deployed Humvee military vehicles equipped with machine guns to the border with Serbia after clashes Wednesday when water cannons and tear gas were used against immigrants trying to cross over despite a razor-wire fence.
At least 20 police officers and two children have been injured in the clashes, Russia Today reports.
So far, 20 policemen have been injured and the ambulance service has taken two children who were injured after being hurled over the security fence.
"We will be re-erecting and reinforcing the fence and we will be protecting Hungarian security by all means," said Hungarian Prime Minister's Security Advisor Gyorgy Bakondi.
Police attempted to control the crowds with water cannon and tear gas as people threw plastic bottles, stones and pavement slabs.
Authorities say several dozen migrants broke through the fence at the border crossing between the towns of Roszke and Horgos and managed to enter the country.
Hungary's foreign minister has demanded that Serbia take action against "very aggressive" migrants at their shared border.
There are reports that the Serbs have bolstered their border patrol.
Budapest has suspended the border crossing at Roszke-Horgos for 30 days following Wednesday's incidents.
Hungary is in a concerted action to close its borders to stave off access to immigrants.

After announcing on Tuesday he would erect a fence along the Hungary-Serbia border, besides the one already in place, to the vehement protests of Bucharest, the Hungarian premier announced Wednesday he would also build a fence along the Hungary-Croatia border.
Rare disease man suffers
American Nick Hess was suspected by his family of being an alcoholic, his wife even filming him when he was drunk, barely able to stand, and slurring his words.
Although the 35-year-old man said he had not consumed alcohol, he was visibly inebriated.
When she first accused me of being drunk, while I hadn't had a drink, I thought she was crazy.
"But friends and family thought 'maybe he's drinking alone, he's a secret alcoholic', he told the Mirror.
When he saw the video of his wife and him, the Columbus, Ohio, man just didn't recognize himself: "I looked in my eyes and I wasn't there."
'It was horrible, I didn't remember anything'.
In addition, his wife, who, while she did have her doubts about him at first, finally went with him to any number of doctors, remembers that Nick's breath even smelled like alcohol.

What really made Nick think was one night when, after a minor accident in which he was hit by another car, he found out that had a blood-alcohol level of three times over the legal limit although the night before, he had only drunk one beer.
After years and countless investigations, it was discovered that Nick suffers from an extremely rare disease, "Auto-brewery syndrome".
Basically, the condition causes all carbohydrates to ferment, turning them into alcohol.
The one who suspected it could be Nick's illness was his own wife.
There's no cure for the disease, but since Nick cut out carbohydrates, he hasn't suffered from any further episodes.
He destroyed a Mercedes with a golf club
A man in South Korea destroyed his Mercedes S63 car in protest at poor service he received from his local dealer.
The man hit his car with a golf club and caused enough damage to make it unusable, BT reported.
The entire scene was filmed and the video was posted on the Internet, to the amusement of those who have watched it.
The man claimed that the vehicle has defects that put his life and family in danger.
He was upset because the car dealer, whom he had bought the car from, didn’t fix the problem as promised.

The government approved on Wednesday the National Immigration Strategy for 2015-2018, and the Action Plan for the current year, documents considered to be "yet another step in the modernization process of the management of immigration on Romania's territory," according to a press release.

The source said the strategy is aimed at managing migration efficiently and includes general strategic objectives, specific objectives, and lines of action that reflect policies set at the European level and adapted to national realities.

Given the problems faced by states in Romania's immediate neighborhood, measures are being considered for the unified and coherent management of situations caused by the possible appearance of an influx of illegal immigrants on Romanian territory, generated by political, social, economic or military crisis situations.

"Romanian authorities will contribute towards creating a flexible admission system, yet they will pay a special attention to citizens coming from states with migration potential or that can threaten the national security," the source further mentioned.

The strategy identifies a number of factors that may influence immigration and asylum, including the persistence of the conflict situation in Syria, the re-activation of the conflict in Iraq, the perpetuation and intensification of the Israeli-Palestinian armed conflict, the maintenance of an unstable situation in the neighboring areas of Romania (Ukraine, Transnistria).

On the other hand, the document also sets some general strategic objectives relating to migration, such as: the promotion of legal migration, more rigorous controls on the legality of the residence of third-country nationals on the territory of Romania, the proper application of removal measures and restrictive measures, the improvement of the national asylum system.
The national strategy also contains specific objectives relevant for the transposition and implementation of the general strategic objectives.

These include: facilitating the access of third-country nationals to Romania for purposes of satisfying the needs of the labour market, facilitating access of third-country nationals to Romanian higher education institutions for the fields and occupations identified as lacking in the Romanian labour market.
The Government believes that the Action Plan for 2015 is "a means of setting out concrete activities to create a flexible system for curbing the growing migratory phenomenon".
Romania, in the European job market top

Latvia, Romania and Bulgaria had the highest increases in the total cost of labour in the second quarter of 2015 compared with the same period of 2014, according to data published by the European Union's statistics office (Eurostat) on Wednesday.
The index refers to employers' payroll expenses.
Thus, in the period April - June 2015, the total cost of labor increased by 1.9% in the EU and 1.6% in the euro zone.
Romania on 3rd Place in EU in terms of Labour Cost Growth
The highest increases were reported in Latvia (7.9%), Romania (7.7%), Bulgaria (6.8%), Estonia (5.5%) and Lithuania (4.3%).
The only EU states to see the hourly labour cost fall in the second quarter of the year were Greece (-2.9%), Cyprus (-1.2%) and Italy (-0.4%).
The increase in labor costs in Romania in the period April - June 2015 is due primarily to the increase in the hourly cost of labor in industry and services, by 7.9% and, respectively, 7.6%.
In construction, the hourly labour cost rate grew 5.8% in Romania.
TVR Board's activity report rejected in commissions: Stelian Tanase risks dismissal
The culture committees of the Parliament rejected Wednesday the activity report of the Board of Administration of the Romanian Television Society for 2014.
Seventeen MPs voted for the rejection of the report, one was against it (senator Varujan Vosganian) and one abstained.
The text of the report will be submitted to the Joint Bureaus.
They will likely decide next week.
It will be discussed in the next plenary meeting.
"I think with this situation it will be done fairly quickly", said Georgica Severin, the chairman of the Senate Culture Committee.
He added that "the presence of the leadership of the TVR was common sense" given the fact that no representative of the TVR leadership was present at the meeting of the culture committees.
It was only logical that the leadership of TVR be present because no one on the inside has been subjected to personal attacks or anything of that nature.

He/She invited the members of the Board of Directors last night, about an hour ago because we did not know the time either, but today, after the meeting of the Bureau, I personally sent a fax to the leadership of the Romanian Television inviting them.
I think that when you are summoned, you being a state employee, paid by public taxes and you are summoned to a meeting of the joint committees even if you don't like it you come.
"It is your duty to work and you are in an institution under the Parliament's responsibility," said Severin after the joint session of the parliamentary culture committees.
He added that the financial aspects of the institution have been discussed based on the negative opinion of the Budget Committees.
We've seen what the debts have been like and we've seen this idea that they'll be paid off this year, but the historical debts haven't been paid off.
"I would remind you that it is not the fault of me or other committees that this agreement with the banks and tax authorities was lost, it's a clear problem of management," Severin said.
He added that following the rejection of the activity report by the joint plenary, elections will follow for a new Board of Directors, which will in turn elect the institution's general manager.
I do not know who will be proposed for this.
Don't expect miracles.
It's important to make political decisions so that this institution can function.
I'm not the one to tell you that a genius is going to stand in line and take his turn.
I hope those who decide, Parliament's plenum, will vote with reason to choose the people who will lead TVR.
There has to be people who know what's going on there, who have experience and who have a lot of correctness and respect for institution and tradition.
I don't know who will be, if you ask me what qualities they should have - good sense in attitude towards employees because it is a pile of petitions that come from employees, complaints, dismissals.
"When you receive such reports 50, 60, 70, something is rotten and we are talking about the financial situation which is a disaster," the president of the Senate's culture committee concluded.

Despite not showing up in Parliament, the president and CEO of the Romanian Television (TVR), Stelian Tanase, sent a letter to the President of the Chamber of Deputies, Valeriu Zgonea, requesting that the Parliament considers a set of measures that could lead to the saving and guaranteeing of the economic and political independence of the public television, among these, also the indexing of the TV tax.

In the letter, Stelian Tanase requests, besides the indexation of TV tax, the modification and completion of HG 978/2003 regarding the tax for the public service of television, so as to update the provisions to the level of the technological changes of today, as well as to regulate the procedure for the control in the payment of the TV tax, and the identification of the offenses and the application of sanctions and penalties.

He also wants a measure to be issued providing the extension of the obligation to all the electricity suppliers to become the SRTv's proxies for the collection of the TV tax, by involving ANRE in the regulation of this activity.
He therefore recommends capping the collections commission at 5%

Stelian Tanase asked for the reduction of the VAT for the activities specific to the public television, and the reduction of the CNC contribution from 15% to 3%, and also for the modification of the law 41/1994, such that (TVR) can receive governmental allocations/funds for the acquisition of licenses for major cultural and sports events - the World Soccer Championship, the Golden Stag, the Eurovision.

He claims that SRTv will go bankrupt in the next few months, given that the labor legislation requires the employer to implement the court decisions, even if they are not final, and salary rights are honored with priority over any other obligation.
The TVR administration has been constantly making efforts to reduce costs of personnel and TV production.

"This resulted in reduced travel and other cost-generating activities, a series of commercial contracts were renegotiated and at the end of July TVR News was closed," the letter of the TVR president stated.
Tanase believes the ruinous financial situation cannot be remedied by their own efforts.

"Without the support of public institutions - Government, Parliament, Presidency - Televiziunea Romana will sooner or later find itself unable to perform the public task it has been entrusted with," the letter reads.
The Chamber of Deputies' leadership decided to send the letter to the House commission on cultural affairs.
Vasile Blaga's son-in-law to stand trial
The son-in-law of Vasile Blaga, Ionut Andrei Rudeanu, was indicted, yesterday, by the prosecutors of the Court of Appeal in Bucharest.
He is accused of tax evasion in a case that caused losses of around 600,000 euros and is under judicial supervision.
Andrei Rudeanu was detained on 22 May.
He founded Axis Corporate Security SRL, together with his mother, in April 2009, a year after he married Vasile Blaga's daughter, Agathe.

It was ascertained that, in order to evade the payment of taxes and duties to the state budget, the representatives of a company specialized in security services would have created a criminal circuit, made up of several commercial companies, through which fictitious transactions would have been evidenced.

Ilie Sarbu has been elected as vice-chairman of the Court of Accounts
The Senate voted on Wednesday to appoint PSD Senator Ilie Sarbu, PM Victor Ponta's father-in-law, as vice-president of the Audit Authority of Court of Accounts.
There were 290 votes in favor and 108 votes against, according to Mediafax.
The vote was secret, with ballots.
The Liberal representatives were the only ones to vote against the proposition, Digi24 informs.
Liberals have criticized Sarbu's appointment and have said they will challenge it in the constitutional court.
Ilie Sarbu has 30 days, according to the law, to resign from the Senate, because his new function at the Court of Accounts does not allow him to do politics anymore.

The PSD senator will take the position of vice-president of the Audit Authority of the Court of Accounts, which became vacant after Ioan Anton was dismissed, following a decision of the Constitutional Court, in September 2014, which found that he was unconstitutionally appointed.
Surprise from one of the sexiest actors: I grew up in the kitchen
Bradley Cooper is set to play a chef in the upcoming film "Burnt", but the actor made a revelation his fans didn't expect.

"It's not a very motivating thing for me to have a map," he said.

At 40 years old, the actor does admit that he sees himself directing in the near future, taking a cue from Clint Eastwood, who started directing at the same age.
Ponta, accused of uncontrolled calumny and irrational statements

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto slammed Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta's remarks that Hungary's decision makers are "no better than those in Syria, Libya or other countries where refugees come from."
"Yesterday, Victor Ponta lost his self-control and, by his irrational statements, he insults the whole of Hungary," the Hungarian Foreign Minister said in a statement.
Civilized European politicians don't make such unbridled calumnies.
"His remarks have a single explanation: he has lost all support in Romania's internal politics," the Hungarian foreign minister added, MTI reported.

In a post on his Facebook page late on Tuesday, Victor Ponta said he wanted to bring attention to and sanction the conduct of certain high-ranking Hungarian government officials, whom he said "are a disgrace to the culture and values of the European Union".
I do not wish to answer provocations from some Hungarian government representatives.

"They are a disgrace to the culture and the values of the European Union -- both in their anti-Semitism, and in their treatment of minorities of all types, and now in the refugee crisis!", said Ponta on Facebook.
Romania's prime minister added that he is an advocate for rational and sustainable solutions for the refugee crisis, saying that brutality and aggressive laws will not solve the problem.

Barbed wire fences, harsh laws, prisons and brutality won't solve the problem - it will just show that in Hungary, in the heart of Europe, its politicians are no better than those in Syria, Libya or any other countries from which the refugees are fleeing!

"I believe in solidarity, in rational and sustainable solutions and, especially, in the superiority of European values - what we are seeing in Hungary in the past few days is in total contradiction with these objectives and values!", said the Romanian prime minister.

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto dismissed as "outright lies" remarks by Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta on the handling of the refugee crisis by Hungary, adding that such statements are inappropriate for a 21st century leader, MTI reported earlier on Tuesday.

Hungary's foreign minister also mentioned on Tuesday that "extremist and false remarks" of the Romanian prime minister are related to the internal political crisis in Romania and that Budapest expects an apology from the Romanian side.
Szijjarto was referring to a statement made by Prime Minister Victor Ponta on Monday.

What I have always said and what I have always maintained is that I am against the xenophobic speeches, the idea of closing the borders and that everybody who is coming is a terrorist, are barbarians, are people of the Middle Ages and I am totally opposed to this approach.
We can take more, we will take more, the question is our logistical capacity to treat those people as human beings, not as the Hungarians treat them, with batons and tear gas.
"I am not in agreement with that", the Romanian PM said in a press conference in Targu-Jiu.

On Tuesday, Peter Szijjarto announced that the Hungarian government had decided to begin preparations on the ground to extend the fence on the border with Romania to face any possible change in the route used by migrants.
