What's the Connection Between Osama bin Laden and Mecca Crane Collapse?

Saudi authorities said Sunday that the kingdom's Binladin Group, owned by the family of Osama bin Laden, is "partially responsible" for a crane collapse at the Grand Mosque in Mecca that killed 107 people Friday.
According to an investigative committee, the company did not "adhere to safety standards", Saudi Press Agency (SPA) reported, BBC said.
Company executives have been barred from leaving the country until the investigation is over.
The company will also be barred from new government contracts.
The construction company is owned by the family of the former leader of the al-Qaida terrorist network, Osama bin Laden.
The company was founded by Osama bin Laden's father 80 years ago and is currently led by the former terrorist leader's brother, Bakr.
The Binladin Group has been working for four years to expand the Grand Mosque to accommodate more pilgrims.
The accident occurred Friday night, during a storm, when a crane, reportedly toppled by strong winds, collapsed on the eastern side of the Grand Mosque in Mecca.
In the aftermath of the crash, 107 people died and nearly 400 were injured.
How did Hagi shut down his opponents

Considered by many to be the greatest Romanian footballer of all time, Gheorghe Hagi has been labelled, after his retirement from the game as a weak coach, one who is incapable of achieving any kind of success in his new role.
After a miserable experience as the national team manager, or as the manager of Steaua or Galatasaray, Hagi took over Viitorul Constanta, the team he had founded, one year ago.
After one year in charge, the King has proved he is capable of turning a team struggling to avoid relegation into a championship contender.
So, after a year, Hagi's Future recorded 16 victories, 11 draws and 11 defeats.
It is the balance sheet of a team that is in the running for a European cup.
Things have turned even better this season for Viitorul, which has risen to second in the league with 19 points, one less than leader Astra Giurgiu.
Future has the best attack in the League 1, with 20 goals (equal to Astra), more than double than Steaua.

However, even if he brought on the team more experienced players, Hagi continued the policy of promoting young people, and in the last period in the starting lineup appeared names such as Ianis Hagi or Hodorogea.

The club's policy made Viitorul a team to watch for foreign teams, so Hagi sold two players in this summer for 1.5 million euros - Ianis Hagi (Fiorentina - 1 million euros) and Alexandru Mitrita (Bari - 500 thousand euros).
Next to Steaua, Viitorul is the only profitable team in Liga 1, according to the Trade Registry.
In the refugee crisis, Romania has played so far as a small country.
It's a legitimate strategy but after that you can't ask to be treated as the seventh EU country.
Big EU countries are coming up with answers for the entire EU, said Cristian Ghinea, a member of the Romanian Center for European Policies management board.

In an interview with Ziare.com, Cristian Ghinea said that Europe cannot be converted into a fortress, and pure police methods will not work in this crisis: "Maybe we have doubts about the quality of the values that these people bring."

But there are masses set in motion and we cannot turn history around.
 
Q: Masele nu sunt oameni, ele nu pot scrie, ele nu pot gândi.
A: The masses are not people, they cannot write, they cannot think.
Migration is a reality that we must adapt to as best as we can and adapt them to us.
According to Cristian Ghinea, we are in a very emotional moment in which politicians feel the need to show their muscles.

After that, Europeans will not be willing to give up on free movement, but the rules of the Schengen area need to be changed: "Schengen is now like an animal created in another epoch and not adapted to today's situation".
Where do we go from here after this Justice and Home Affairs Council meeting that actually has resolved nothing?
It is clear that the President of the EC, in agreement with Donald Tusk, did not want to force a vote in the Council.
All the polls said he had the necessary votes.
Before the Lisbon Treaty, the JHA operated on the principle of unanimity and any state could block any decision.
Therefore, things have been very little integrated into the field of justice and home affairs.
Following Lisbon, the normal procedure is that the Commission takes the initiative, and the Council approves it voting 55%, i.e. 16 states, that represent 65% of the EU population.
The counting said the votes were there.
But they didn't want to move on.

Because it's a sensitive issue, there have been reactions against the opening policy of Chancellor Merkel even in Germany, and they did not want this to appear as a reaction of the kind "EU sends us migrants on our heads".
So they have postponed it, but the problem remains because obviously this wave is creating a huge problem for Schengen governance and we will probably see big changes there in the near future.
So the mandatory quotas weren't really eliminated, the subject was just left to cool?

Yes, on the other hand, there's talk of a greater involvement of the Frontex agency in managing the external borders, which means a move from the individual responsibility of those who are at the external border of the Schengen zone to the responsibility of the community agencies.
The Greek-Turkish border is also the de facto German-Turkish border, and this wave of migrants has brought the limits of the old Schengen system to the fore.
The Dublin principle, which holds that migrants are the responsibility of the first country they enter, may be abandoned because it's not sustainable.
If Greece sinks, you can't say forever that it's just Greece.
It's a common problem.
Since the problem is common, can a solution be found without a specific, perhaps even compulsory, mechanism for sharing the burden of hosting?
Nobody knows exactly how the mandatory quotas will work, if they will be implemented at all.
But there is a catch: what happens if the person doesn't want to come to Romania or Portugal, but to Sweden or Germany?
I do not believe that European states will start taking migrants by force: you go to country X or to country Y.
Probably there will be built some central processing centres in Greece or Turkey, where the asylum requests will be processed.
Workarounds of this kind are being worked on.
But the problem is not easy to solve.

There are countries which have decades of experience trying to integrate migrants, and there are countries, like Romania, with no experience and where the migrant issue will increase the xenophobic current.
Certainly, we're talking about millions of people who are in Turkey, in Lebanon, in Jordan, who are in makeshift camps and who are only just starting to leave in large numbers for Europe.
Only about 10% managed to get away, winter is a hard time to cross the Mediterranean, but next year we're expecting a wave that could even be bigger.
What do we do with these people?
My prediction is that we're going to get used to this problem, we will not see it as catastrophic from a media standpoint.
You spoke of countries with more or less experience.
Do you think there is a place where the integration of large groups from a non-European culture really succeeded?
I look at the Maghrebis in France, the Turks in Germany, they are all still enclaved.
As i would not go towards radical statements.
Yes, their integration is more difficult than in the case of other waves of migration, but that doesn't mean they don't integrate at all.
There is this unassimilated part which is creating really big social problems in France, in Germany, in Britain.
But police tactics won't work.
To create a Fortress Europe is illusory.
The integration mechanisms into European societies should be put under scrutiny.
Here were some mistakes.
We have to be more demanding.

Let's ask these people to learn the language, try to adopt the values, to let go of the one foot in Europe and the other one in their home countries, bringing their families over too, even through marriages of convenience.
But the imminent problem of these people should be separated from the long-term issue of their integration.
If others have failed in long-term integration, it doesn't mean that we should look at them drowning in the Mediterranean.
Maybe we have doubts about the quality of the values these people bring.
And if there is a Syrian intervention, which I don't think there will be, it doesn't mean that the country will be rebuilt overnight and you can send them back.
Until we have the solution, we’ll see fortresses in Europe.
Borders are being closed, walls are being erected, border controls are being introduced.
Is the European project in danger?
The European project itself, no. The Schengen area as it was constructed, yes.
It’s been quite minimal and arranging the rules so that the pressure has been too much on the countries that these migrants step foot in for the first time.
We are moving around freely, but everyone is dealing with its own problems.
In the face of such a wave, not all countries can cope.
When there are waves of emotion like there are now, politicians want to show that they are doing something, but in the long run little changes.
We do not yet have a much more draconian antiterror legislation in the EU than we did last year.
It's a wave of public emotion.
And it's so unstable from week to week that you can't make decisions based on it.
We have a lot of rhetoric, a lot of tough talk from politicians who are at home under pressure to be macho.
And then the dramatic case of the child who drowned in Turkey and the public is being affected.
After the public emotion passes, we will return to the reasons we created this space, this freedom of movement that is not only for people, but also for goods.
It is the European single market.
And I don't think the Europeans will forgo on this principle of freedom of movement.
That there will be other rules is another thing.
Schengen is now like an animal created in a different era and not adapted to the current situation.
How has Romania played out so far in this crisis?
As a small country that believes that if you pull the cap over your eyes and stuff your ears, the issue will disappear.
It is not a great choice in the face of the reality that there are waves of migrants. You can choose to be part of the solution or you can say it is not your problem, being a small country.
We did that, it's a legitimate strategy, but then you can't ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
You aren't, you aren't playing country big.
The big countries come with solutions for the entire EU, good or bad, we're not discussing their quality right now.
As did Poland.
On the other hand, the effect of this crisis is that the Romanian appetite for Schengen will decrease greatly.
President Iohannis said it was probably good that we had not joined already.
So we move from despairing entry to a more pragmatic position, but the goal remains the same.
There is a risk of course if Romania and Bulgaria enter Schengen that we will be seen as an alternative route.
But that should not be taken as a reason not to join Schengen, but rather to be more pragmatic.

Romania will be part of the Schengen area and the Schengen will exist, but changed so that the external borders become a joint responsibility, there will be a single set of rules for the acceptance of migrants, a single set of rules for deportation for those who do not receive asylum, a single set of rules for countries considered safe.

Is there a connection between the two outbreaks, is it a Russian game?
Russia has a behavior of a frustrated power.
She believes that being a great power means annoying the Americans and the Europeans.
From this point of view yes, there is a link.
Without the Putin regime's military and financial support, the Assad regime would probably have collapsed by now.

Then the Islamic State emerged and now we do not know if we want the Assad regime to fall.
Russia could complicate things, but it cannot participate in the solution.

Playing off-side is just a strategy to win time.
Probably Putin is waiting to be made offers, to press buttons to resolve the situation.

But I don't buy the theory that these people are driven by an invisible hand.
Let's not see Putin stronger than he is.
What button will appear soon
Millions of Facebook users have become familiar with the "Like" button, and now the social network is preparing to introduce an opposite button, the "Dislike."
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced on his Facebook page Tuesday that the social media website will soon include a "dislike" button, the New York Times reported.
Zuckerberg said the "dislike" button would reflect more of a shade of what a user is feeling than a simple vote.
However, his announcement raises the question of whether Facebook could become a less friendly place.
Zuckerberg said he wanted to avoid the moments where someone posts a major life event and someone else gives them the "thumbs down".
Users of the network, which has 1.5 billion active accounts, have long been asking for the ability to express negative emotions or empathy with something sad.
Zuckerberg also said that he isn't comfortable with people giving a "like" to current events, such as the refugee crisis or death of a family member.
"You may not feel comfortable liking that post," the Facebook rep pointed out.
Not everyone is happy about the new Facebook button.
"There is already plenty of hate on Facebook and social media", commented Atiq Haneef from Afghanistan on the New York Times website's Facebook page, where the article about this was posted.
"I'm going to 'Dislike' the 'Dislike' button," he said.
Roger Anderson, a microbiologist from Atlanta, claimed there was nothing wrong with the button, encouraging people to have different opinions on Facebook.
Debra Aho Williamson, a social media analyst with eMarketer, noted that it is hard to imagine that a single button can convey a complex range of negative emotions.
The "Dislike" button would create a "disaster," she says, especially with the U.S. election coming up.
Only 70 refugees entered Hungary in 24 hours
Hungary accepted only 70 migrants on Tuesday, a handful of the thousands who have been pouring across its southern border with Serbia, government spokesman Gyorgy Bakondi said.

Hungary declared a state of emergency on Tuesday in two counties along the border with Serbia because of the flow of refugees, closing a main border crossing point and announcing that it will build a border fence with Romania, Deutsche Presse-Agentur recalls.
The measure has drawn a sharp response from Serbia.
They say they will seal the border to those who want to cross but not those who want to seek asylum.
"As you see, it is totally different," Serbian Minister for Refugees Aleksandar Vulin said.
Before the introduction of the new immigration legislation, a record number of 5,809 migrants entered Hungary on Sunday, police said on Monday.
Also, over 170,000 migrants from the Middle East and Africa have crossed into Hungary from Serbia in 2015.
Many try to avoid being registered and try to reach the West, especially Germany.
The "new" headquarters of the County Council is about to fall.
Two contractors in insolvency
The massive investment here in recent years to move the institution is falling apart because it has been stalled again and again.
Two major builders that worked here went bankrupt during construction.
The County Council headquarters on Vasile Alecsandri Street will collapse by itself.
More than a year and a half after the consolidation and refunctionalization works were supposed to be completed, the works are not even half done.

The last chapter in the saga of the unfinished headquarters of the Romanian Intelligence Service (SRI) was written recently when the National Council for Solving Complaints (CNSC) dismissed a complaint of the company that wanted to take over the contract for the technical design of the works to be completed.
The initial project was drawn up by Impex Romcatel SA.

After the builder's bankruptcy and the suspension of works, negotiations procedures were initiated without a public call for tenders, with Impex Romcatel being asked to update the technical project and then for a new tender for the works to be organized.

"However, the negotiations did not end in a contract, CJ arguing that the proposed form would have been detrimental to the institution," summarized Răzvan Timofciuc, public relations representative at CJ.
The CJ's decision to suspend direct negotiations has been challenged in court by Impex Romcatel.
The Iasi court has sent the complaint to the National Council for the Fight Against Discrimination, which rejected it as untimely.
This doesn't mean, however, that CJ can start looking for another designer.
Impex Romcatel can appeal the CNSC decision to the Court of Appeal, only after a final ruling being taken into account finding another designer.
Thus, consolidation works of the building might be resumed as of next year.
Our intention is to resume work as soon as possible.
In principle, the technical reworking of the project should not take long, but we need to finish a contract.
"We are waiting to see if the decision of the CNSC will be contested or not," Timofciuc said.
The consolidation works of the former Police Headquarter started in 2011.
A first work contract was canceled in April 2012, after works worth 4.5 million lei were done.
The tender was re-launched, the contract being won by Moldoconstruct SA.
But the company was declared insolvent and the contract was terminated after payments of $1.5 million were made.
The work has been finished to the tune of about 50%.
The initial works of consolidation, refunctionalization and mansard of the building were evaluated at 7.7 million lei.

One of the employees involved in the scandalous Cadastre Office file has signed a pretrial agreement, acknowledging the facts.
Most likely, Dirceu's testimony will incriminate the other defendants, including his former boss, Narciza Nedelcu
A real estate cadastre and publicity office (OCPI) consultant from Iasi, accused by the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) in a corruption case, confessed to the charges.
The plea bargain agreement signed by Dumitru Dascălu was recorded yesterday in Iași Court, judges deciding to give a solution in this case on September 29.
Dumitru Daniel Dascălu was charged with continuous intellectual fraud and agreed to serve two years in jail, deferred, as well as community service.

Regarding the charges against Dascălu, prosecutors said he, along with other colleagues, "as a counselor at the Cadastre Office, has prepared several false minutes of acceptance, concerning service contracts previously concluded by the Cadastre Office Iași with the administrators of SC Gauss SRL, SC Grup Cinci SRL, SC Topo Euro Cad SRL, SC Agenția de Ca­dastru și Topografie SRL și PFA Lipșa Ștefan, which attest, unrealistically, that the contracted services were fully completed, while in fact they were not and were not submitted to the Cadastre Office."
The other charges include refunding money to certain companies for services that were not performed.
The damage amounts to more than 300,000 lei.
Stone Age Adventures

According to Alexandru Dedu, the president of the Romanian Handball Federation, Romania can host a major handball competition only in 2024, and preparing the women's handball team for qualifying for the Olympic Games is costing a fortune.

Alexandru Dedu, the president of the Romanian Handball Federation, said in a meeting with the press yesterday that it was a great honor that our country has three teams in the Champions League groups.

For the Romanian women's national handball team, "the main goal is the Olympic Games qualification for Rio de Janeiro, but for that it has first to overcome two hell phases, namely the World Championship and then the qualification tournament", Dedu also said.
We really want to qualify for the Olympic Games.
It is a fantastic ask from Tomas Ryde's technical staff.
The team will consist of seven or eight people.
He wants an assistant coach, medic, two masseurs, goalkeeper coach, fitness coach, delegation chief.
They asked us for some things for qualification, specifically physical education materials, that I have never heard of.
I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get there. And I will do whatever it takes to have them.
We're talking about a massive investment, there's a lot of, a lot of money.
But this is the way to be performance.
Because at the moment we are in the stone age with the preparation.
"The teams we are fighting have these materials and have had them for some time," Dedu said, adding he is trying to get the necessary funds to buy the products from MTS and COSR.
The EHF president also referred to Romania's infrastructure and the possibility for our country to host a major handball competition.
We don't have a room in Bucharest.
It is an infrastructure problem and it is shameful to have a European gymnastics championships called into question.
Let us not forget that in other parts of the world Olympic villages have been built in their entirety in a two-year period.
Before 1992, the current Olympic zone in Barcelona was a dump, and now it has become a beacon of beauty.
The same was true in London, where the 2012 Olympics were a success in terms of investments.
"In my vision, in 2024 we can host a major competition," Dedu said.
He added that the international handball bodies would be willing to grant Romania the organization of a major competition.
It is a priority for me to bring major handball competitions to Romania.
Mr. Gațu went to the village in a civilized way with a project, the people gave their approval in principle, but they soon realized that the hall will never be built.

I also discussed with EHF, I said that we want, and we are able to organize and they said that they are in agreement and to invite them to the first game in the new stadium in Bucharest and then discuss concrete details.
"So we have all the openness, both at EHF and at IHF, but we don't have the infrastructure", the FRH official explained.

The former Handball great avoided to evaluate the chances of CSM Bucharest and HCM Baia Mare to reach the Final Four: "I asked all the coaches to be reserved in their predictions, because if they don't come true, they will turn against them."
Clear Path to World Cup
Romanian rugby players begin on 23 September against France

Romania's national rugby team captain Mihai Macovei said on Tuesday at a press conference that all team members are ready for the Rugby World Cup matches in England, where they hope to win two games: "We are ready."
Both me and my colleagues are in high gear.
We trained to put in the best four games.
Everybody's going to expect a lot, because our goal is to win two games, against Canada and Italy.
All groups are difficult, including ours.
Let's take it easy, first with France, and then we will see.
It is certain we will win against Canada. Our match against Italy will be our final.
I can't describe in words the joy of playing in the World Cup, it's the culmination of years of hard work.
I want to let nobody down who follows us in the rugby world and come home with some good results.
"We want you to be proud that some players, a small family as the Romanian rugby is, proudly represent the tricolour,'' said Macovei.
Romania coach Lynn Howells, making his first appearance at a World Cup, hopes his players will make their country proud: "It's a great honour for us to be taking part in the World Cup."
I am sure the players are prepared to take part in the tournament.
It's an extraordinary experience for me.
It is very important to me that I make Romanians proud at every match.
The President of the Romanian Rugby Federation, Haralambie Dumitraş, is confident that the Romanian rugby players can confirm the progress made in recent years in rugby.
We have a very difficult group and we want to confirm the progress made by the national team.
The team of athletes will be at the height of the event.
"These guys started to play in the Romanian national teams when they were 18-19 years old, so there's cohesion, it's a group of friends, who set their minds to make a dream come true," Dumitras said.

The competition kicks off Friday at Twickenham Stadium in London with England-Fiji in group A.
New Japanese Culture Courses at "Al.I. Cuza" University
You can learn about flower arrangement in a vase, painting in monochrome, but also a light study about the fine arts of the Land of the Rising Sun at courses organized by the Iasi students.
The Iasi Japanese Culture Students' Circle organises new Japanese culture courses (ikebana, sumie and fine arts) between October 2015 and June 2016, courses for both beginners and experienced people.
They will take place at the European Studies Centre of the "Alexandru Ioan Cuza" University of Iasi and are organized with the aim of promoting traditional and modern Japanese arts and culture.
There is a single participation fee of 50 RON per person, per month.
Apart from taking art lessons, participants will be able to take part in the making of exhibitions and other cultural activities promoting beauty.
The Japanese culture courses we've suggested are designed as an invitation to the general public to make the first steps on the road to self-knowledge through art.

"Those interested will be able to learn how to create harmonious floral sculptures (ikebana), how to capture the soul of the environment in plastic compositions using the Japanese art of painting in ink (Sumie) or how to express their own individuality and creativity through the multivalent universe of fine arts (graphic, drawing, painting) ", said Sorin Mazilu, the professor of these courses.
The courses are offered to all those passionate about art, regardless of age or experience.
Entries will be accepted until September 30, and those interested in more information can call 0742.027.153 or e-mail studenticultura@gmail.com.
14 million lei given to the "Sf. Spiridon" Hospital in Iași at the budget amendment
What is being purchased with this large sum of money?
The "St. Spiridon" Hospital received from the Ministry of Health, following the budget amendment, about 14 million lei.

The money that the medical unit has received to be used until the end of the year will be invested in modernization and setting up some clinics, but also in medical equipment and techniques for which the hospital has already begun the procedure for public procurement.

Thus, the healthcare facility will be equipped with new computer tomography and radiology apparatus, six surgical intervention kits, six intensive care unit beds with the corresponding equipment, an ophthalmic microscope and other necessary medical equipment.
On the other hand, 5 million lei out of the money received by the hospital will be directed to the construction and development of the "Great Art".
From the budget rectification, UPU will receive 500,000 lei to finish the modernization works in the main section.

"Plus, over the coming days, we will accept the bridge works between the Emergency Unit and the Cardiology, Hepatology and Gastroenterology clinics to ensure decent transport of patients from the Emergency Unit to the nearby clinics," the medical unit manager also explained.
The hospital will soon have in the yard and the Dermatology Clinic in Tatarasi, which will be organized in outpatient care, under the same form as it currently operates.
The clinic will be located where the allergology, hematology, and endocrinology sections of the outpatient clinic are and will have about 30 beds.
Iasi makes a joke of RATP controllers and a leaflet
A tourist trap
A family of tourists from Cluj came to Iasi to visit him, but the excursion ended with a bitter promise.
After the experience we have had neither I nor my wife want to set foot in your town again.
Unwittingly, they bumped into the wrong information from leaflets, the unprofessional behavior of RAPT controllers, and, bonus, with a fine "because so says the law."
The couple arrived in Iasi a few days ago, booked a hotel in downtown and asked for touristic brochures.
They also got a brochure listing the routes of the RATP.
Armed with these maps, the spouses visited Iasi.
But, two days ago, they were in Copou and wanted to get to Palas Mall.
Because there was no ticket booth at the station by Copou Park, they relied on the information printed on the flyer: that they could take a ticket by SMS.
No one told them this service no longer exists.
Confident in the leaflet, they boarded a bus and tried to send an SMS according to the instructions on the leaflet.
Unfortunately for them, a team of RATP controllers turned up.
They said that the service has not existed for 2 years (already) and that it was announced in the press that it had been canceled.
How am I supposed to know what's in the local papers, me coming in the evening before to visit the city?
I talked to the controllers, I explained the situation, they said they don't care, it's not their business.
The attitude is very defiant.
They said that all they can do is give us a single fine instead of two (mine and my wife's).
"I paid the fine, I did not want to spoil my visit by standing at the police station and making statements there!", Ovidiu says.
In conclusion, the family was fined for the wrong information on the leaflet and for the "blood thirsty" conductors who enforced the law.
It is not correct and I made a complaint to RATP Iasi to get my money back.
It's not about money, it's not a huge amount, but the idea is that I felt cheated.
Bad luck for the criminals in Vaslui.
He had an accident and was left in preventive custody
The trial of the seven rapists from Vaslui was moved yesterday to the Court of Appeal in Iași.
The Iasi magistrates have tried the first term of a closed trial in which the seven young people accused of making fun of an 18-year-old girl have asked to be released.
Prior to the beginning of the court session, one of the judges, Viorel Munteanu, requested to be recused from the case, which was granted by his colleagues.

The magistrate had been working until this summer in Vaslui Court, where he was the president of the Penal Section, being the one who, on April 9, admitted a contestation formulated by four of the defendants, ordering their placement under house arrest.
The case is being handled by a team of judges headed by Maricica Mititelu and Geta Sandu.
Earlier, judge Dan Anton recused himself in the case, saying his daughter was living with one of the rapists' lawyers.
The two judges ruled that the Vaslui rapists will remain under preventive detention.
The teenagers will remain behind bars for at least another 30 days, when judges will re-examine the possibility of their release.
The next hearing will take place at the Iasi Court of Appeals on October 6th.
A minivan transporting the Vaslui rapists to the Iasi Court of Appeals was involved in a traffic accident in Păcurari, a neighborhood of the city, before it reached the center.
The Iveco van used by the seven rapists hit a Volkswagen coming out of Canta street and the driver tried to turn left.
The van was driving from the other end of Păcurari.
The car entered Iași this way because the employees of the Penitentiary Administration preferred the route from Vaslui to Iași, through Grajduri, then on the ring road.
They cut several miles off the journey.
Following the crash, the prisoners' escort summoned another transport to take them to their destination.
Shortly after, a vehicle fom the Maximum Security Prison in Iasi was sent to the scene and took the seven detainees to the Appeals Court.
No one arrested in the incident was injured.
The guards surrounded the back of the cars to move the prisoners to the other van, and the detainees came out briskly, two by two.

"The incident was not reported to the Police because the drivers of both cars agreed amicably as to the damages to be paid," said Police Commissioner Mădălin Țăranu, from the County Police Inspectorate.
Large-scale migration
Romania is not and will not be prepared for what will follow.
But Europe?

From the outset, I will say clearly and firmly: the up to 7,000 refugees Romania should and must naturalise represent, in themselves, a negligible number, but an enormous one in comparison with the Romanian state's capacity to manage such a project.
Even the voluntary quota proposed by Bucharest, amounting to about 1,500 souls, exceeds our good intentions of solidarity with the European Union expressed in the last few months.
In any case, if the migrants were to accept to settle in our communities, their chances to integrate rapidly into the Romanian society are extremely small.
They will be the first to lose their patience.
Plagued by mobsters and immobilized by a venal political class, the Romanian state is proving helpless across the board.
The inability to integrate gypsies is just a banal example.

In addition, governments of all colours have failed to absorb European funds, to build roads, kindergartens or modern schools, to provide decent medical care, to pick up garbage off the streets, to create well-paid jobs or to keep their own young generation at home.
Why would refugees settle in another country they're fleeing from?
But what is most striking is the hypocrisy with which such a crisis is treated.
First we have the military belligerence of the EU's powerful states, showing the utmost generosity in sharing misery with smaller countries.

Next comes the cowardly hypocrisy of Romanians, who, even though they have millions of relatives scattered across the world, still can't accept the other - the one who speaks a different language, has a different religion, or different blood.
Probably so nobody steals his national being.
Finally, there is the hypocrisy of many migrants who claim they are fleeing only war and accept no destination other than Germany or the Nordic countries.
Not all refugees are Syrian and there is no war in Pakistan.
Moreover, the simplistic way in which the crisis is analysed can only be ridiculed.
Some argue that the causes should be removed, relying solely on the card of political correctness and call for peace and investment in the countries of origin of migrants.
But in Romania there is peace and even some foreign capital sometimes comes into the national economy - but that does not stop tens of thousands of Romanians leaving their country every year.
Why are they leaving?
The crisis shows the European Union as a rigid and divided edifice, way behind the curve.
(I) was lamenting the fact that Romania is unable to come up with a national project, but the EU doesn't seem to have any plan for the future either.
Improvisations and threats don't help.
So what is the point of the EU if the one advantage Romanians had - the right to free movement - could be put in question because of the waves of refugees that are crossing borders like cheese?
The war in Syria will eventually end.
Not so the migrant crisis.
In the coming decades, overpopulation, poverty, climate change, resource depletion, etc. will push millions of desperate migrants, mostly from Asia and Africa, to move toward a better life.
With such politicians, Romania is not, nor will it ever be prepared for what is to come.

Two brothers, 9 and 11-year-old, from Tomești (Iași County), swallowed several Diazepam pills.

EXCLUSIVE: A heart-wrenching meeting.
Foster Teen Gets Brave Gift: Her Biological Parents

Lost in a hospital under unclear conditions in the 90s while she was only two months old, weak and helpless, and then adopted by a wealthy family in Italy in the same years when adoption was vaguely regulated, a young Iasi woman, now a beautiful blonde girl, met yesterday in Iasi with her biological parents from a village in the county, after almost two decades in which nobody knew anything about the others.

20-year-old Crina is soon going to celebrate her birthday and her adoptive parents from Palermo have decided to offer their beloved daughter a wonderful and courageous gift: a trip to Romania, to Iasi, to find out more about her unclear past.
The Iași Newspaper, who has been following the efforts to search for the family of origin after some extremely vague clues, has been witness to these meetings which practically break your heart.
The reporters' story, the emotional moments, the statements of those involved, their reactions are truly touching and overwhelming.
Crina's story starts 20 years ago in the village of Ruginoasa, when she was only 2 months old.
Then, because of a health problem, the girl had to be hospitalized in the city.
Discords between parents started to appear at home, and the mother had to leave the household.
He decided to keep the child and send me home.
He stopped the girl, and since then I didn't know anything more.
"When I found out she was in the hospital, it was too late," says Alina, the girl's biological mother.

Crina was hospitalized together with her grandmother in the municipal hospital of Pascani, and that was when the girl's father, Costica Balcan, has left to work in the city of Alexandria, Teleorman County.
Their lives were to part forever.
They didn't find Crina at the hospital
After the internment, Crina's father left for work in another city and he returned after six months.
Meanwhile, the girl was transferred to a hospital in Iași, and the father, when he returned, did not find her.
I think it had been almost nine months since the girl had been in the hospital.
"He must have thought it had been abandoned," a relative said.
The grandmother couldn't afford to bring Crina to Iasi, so the girl was left in the care of the doctors.

Since no one has been interested in the child's fate in all this time, she was taken over by the General Directorate for Social Assistance and Child Protection Iasi, which then gave her to the care of Bucium Placement Center.
It was a time when Romania had more relaxed rules for adoption and abandonment.
The Bucium Center was found by the Italian Salvadore and his wife, a couple from Palermo (sic) who wanted to have their baby, but they failed.
They instantly fell in love with blond Crina, and after a while she moved permanently with them in Italy.
The little girl was already almost two, the length of time the adoption formalities had taken.
When I saw Crina, I felt like she was our daughter.
"As if my wife had given her life," he says smiling, as he takes the frail girl's hand in his.
Back in their home country, Crina's parents, Alina and Costică, continued the search separately, each in their own way.
The father asked the authorities from Ruginoasa but he did not get any answer where his child could be.
Police had then told them that she could have been dead but only in Iasi they had found out what really happened to their daughter.
When I looked for her here at the courthouse they told me she was in Italy, in Palermo.
And I had no more conditions to look for it.
We prayed to God that it will be fine.
I've thought about her all those years, but there was no way to go and find her.
'It's hard,' Crina's biological mother told us, with tears in her eyes.
But even after all these years, the parents in Ruginoasa have not been forgotten.
In Italy, Salvadore and his wife explained to their daughter where she comes from and that her past connects her to Romania.
I was young when I found out.
I think I was five or six.
I reacted like a child, I was curious.
"I wanted to meet my parents from Romania," said Crina happily.
And her dream was about to come true.

In March this year, Chief Commissioner Romică Ichim, director of the Regional Centre for Prevention, Assessment and Drug Counselling of Iasi, was contacted by someone from Italy who explained Salvadore's desire to find Crina's biological family.
And searches started at just a name.
Upon request from our partners in Italy, we have started the first actions.
I had only one name, Balcan Costică, and then the place, Ruginoasa.
Shortly after I had an activity with the mayor there, and I was able to ask if there were any streets in the village by that name.
They gave me some indications, but the person they found was not the one they were looking for.
“We eventually found the girl’s biological father after nearly a month”, Chief Commissioner Romică Ichim explains.
Altogether, for over three months, it took the authorities to find Costică and Alina, especially since each one of them had his/her permanent residence in a different locality.
We began the procedure in March and in June-July we finalized the identification of biological parents and the discussions.
'Then we agreed that in September we shall have the first meeting,' added R. Ichim.
The weekend just gone, Alina and Costică saw their lost daughter for the first time on the corridors of the hospital in Iași, 20 years ago.
The father, emotional, could barely hold back the tears, and his hands trembled constantly.
He barely spoke with the people around him.
A week before the meeting he could hardly sleep.
He was all moved, trembling.
"It's something to see your child after so many years", one of his granddaughters, who came with Costica from Ruginoasa, says.
Crina's Meeting with Biological Mom and Brother

Discussing with his daughter who will be going to study in a very well-ranked university in Italy, Costică Balcan told her, among other things, that if she ever wants to come back to him, in the village, she should come at ease: he can give her some sheep and goats, so that she can find a boy from the village and build up a household.
Mother is also emotional and cries and she doesn't believe such a thing could happen to her.
I am very excited.
I did not believe that this could happen.
I have seen these cases on TV, I have thought about these things for years, I have hoped, but I have not thought that I could be in such a situation.
There are very strong emotions.
If you could forgive me.
I hope to see you in the future.
"I hope we can keep in touch", Alina, the mother of Crina, tells us, with tears rolling down her cheeks, while clutching a paper tissue.
He also hides his tears, out of joy, because soon he will see his daughter after so much bitterness.
On the other hand, Crina, who will turn 20 years old this month, tries to calm herself like an emotional child.
She doesn’t know what to expect, but has a vague idea of what her biological parents might be like.
He thinks they are young, but now before the meeting he tries to gather his thoughts, because he has a lot to say, but nothing to reproach.
My parents are two mothers and two fathers.
But my parents are really the ones who raised me.
It will be a nice meeting, a wonderful experience.
"I'm hoping that I get a nice memory of them, because now there are so many things to say," Crina confesses.
First family reunion in Iași
In Union Square, under a late summer sky, the family from Ruginoasa is once again uniting its fate with their daughter from Palermo.
Crina is now 20 years old, she's finishing high school, after the Italian school model, but she can start a new chapter with Alina and Costica, her biological parents.
The only barrier that separates them is the language.
With the help of a translator, the owner of a restaurant in the center of Iasi, a man with Italian origins, reviewed the documents with ease.
Those who organized the meeting say it is the first of its kind, and that if the opportunity presents itself again, they will do it again.
It is the first event of this scale organized, of such emotional weight, and I'm happy to see it a success.
Here, at the center, we have different activities and we are most of the time associated as an institution that is only taking care of drug-users, people who are consuming drugs.
But we're trying to give back to society something good.
"If I will be asked to take part in such an event, I will do it with great pleasure", said smiling Romică Ichim, director of the Iași Regional Centre for Drug Prevention, Assessment and Counselling.
Behind it, the Balcan family, with Crina in the middle, walk off telling stories.
It’s understandable: they have a lot to talk about.

Everyone is holding their breath
Factions in the Iasi branch of Romania's Social Democratic Party (PSD) have reached an armistice at gunpoint.
After a succession of talks on Friday through Sunday, the first of which was the most tense, PSD leaders agreed to temporarily suspend hostilities.
Pressured by party president Liviu Dragnea to present a united position, the Social Democrats of Ialomita will send him a long list of potential candidates for the party positions.
Far from being over, the internal party war appears to have taken a breather to allow the combatants to catch their breath.
Dragnea didn't give an ultimatum.
He sent a very simple, very current message at this time, that try to find a solution to not put the party in risk.
We have elections in the party on October 3.

All of the positions will be open to those who will want them.
 
Q: Șeful poliției din Malawi a fost arestat marți pentru presupusa implicare în dezaprobata reținere a trei jurnaliști străini la sfârșitul lunii trecute, relatează agenția de presă Associated Press.
A: The police chief of Malawi was arrested Tuesday for his alleged involvement in the controversial detention of three foreign journalists last week, the Associated Press reports.

The two days of talks over the weekend left only the conclusion that nothing was settled.
At the October local elections for the position of the PSD county president is expected a fierce competition.

The shortlist of possible candidates for the main position in the Iași branch of the party includes state secretary Maricel Popa, Senator Florin Constantinescu, Senator Sorin Lazăr, county councilor Vasile Câtea and interim county council president Victorel Lupu.
Schitu Duca Mayor Mihai Mihalache may be added to the list.

The Social-Democratic Party (PSD) is considering the candidacy of the head of the county councilors, Cristian Stanciu, in case Lupu will not enter the race, sources inside the party saying that he is not interested in the position.
The only name not mentioned by any of the participants in the negotiations of the past days is that of the former leader of the party's local branch, Mayor Gheorghe Nichita.

Until the organization of the internal elections, the management of the county branch of PSD will be ensured by Victor Lupu, a close ally of Nichita and Stanciu.

Lupu, however, is on vacation until September 29 and the election preparation will be handled by the association's executive secretary, local councillor Mihail Popescu, who is in bad relations with the Nichita camp.
Reached by phone, Cristian Stanciu described the last few days' discussions as leading to a "partial consensus".
There is a wide availability to keep the balance and the unity in the party.
Partial consensus has been reached, in terms of supporting a unified team to deal with the county.
"However, there are various options concerning the intention to run for presidency of the Iasi PSD, the list remaining open", commented Stanciu.

Corbyn, Brexit and Europe's Future
For economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity that it has enjoyed for the last few decades, can not continue in the same way in the coming years.
Until Saturday most people in Romania didn't know who Jeremy Corbyn was.

Even today, after he has become the new leader of Britain's Labour Party, many are asking to what extent the election of a politician who, after all, is not in a position of decision-making power can affect us.
Jeremy Corbyn is the most left-wing Labour leader since the war.

An avowed Marxist and anti-monarchist (he once demanded that Tony Blair, at the time prime minister, evict the royal family from Buckingham Palace), a fierce anti-American and a supporter of Vladimir Putin (he was regularly invited to comment on political events by the "Russia Today" TV channel), and the Hizbollah and Hamas terrorist movements, he wants Britain to give up nuclear weapons and to leave NATO and the EU.
For Corbyn, who at the time considered the killing of Osama bin Laden a "tragedy," ISIS is preferable to the United States.
Like all populist demagogues, Corbyn has, of course, miraculous anti-austerity solutions.
Things like the ones Tsipras was saying and promising in Greece, until he ran into the real world and the economic legacies.

The economic programme of the new Labour leader includes, among other things, massive renationalisation and printing money as a way to fund developmental projects and to cover some very generous social benefits.
Sure, some might wonder why the solution of printing money is not universally adopted around the globe, then we would have a global prosperity!, but who would bother such details.

Sure, we can tax bankers to the hilt, who have become a kind of a left-wing enemy of sorts, but as we've seen time and again in the past, not just in the former communist states or in Ecuador or Venezuela, but also in France during the beginning of Mitterand and Hollande's mandates.
The extra money is quickly gobbled up by the generous, unfunded promises made by populist demagogues.
As Margaret Thatcher once famously remarked, "the trouble with socialism is that eventually you run out of other people's money".
Few people believe Jeremy Corbyn has any chance of becoming prime minister.
In the early 1980s another old-school left-winger, Michael Foot, who was not as left-wing as the new leader, failed miserably at the polls.
And there was still a working class in Britain in the classic sense of the term, relatively strong and structured.
And the unions were much more influential than now.

In the new industrial landscape, in which services dominate the workforce, and extensive automation means that highly-skilled labor is required massively in industry, Corbyn's rhetoric has limited appeal.
But even from the opposition, he can influence important developments that can directly affect us.
In its last number the Financial Times considers that Corbyn's election increases the chances of Brexit and the exit of Great Britain from the EU.
New Labour leader has been a consistent opponent of the country's membership of the union.
For radical leftists Brussels is the agent of international capitalism and a promoter of globalization who imposed austerity on the poor.

When you combine this kind of idea with those expressed by the radical right, with its anti-immigration rhetoric and look at the refugee crisis that is shaking the foundations of the EU you end up with an explosive mix.
Not just for Britain.

But if the British decide in a referendum that is to be held by 2017 to leave the EU, they will cause a loss of symbolic capital for the entire European project and the deep cracks created within it by the euro crisis and now by that of the refugees between north and south, between east and west, leave room for the most disturbing scenarios.
All the more so because for a whole series of member states, London was a counterbalance to the Franco-German axis (in which Berlin is becoming increasingly dominant anyway).
It is true, Britain's business community, The City, are strong advocates of the country remaining in the EU.
But Europe today is not what it was in the past.
There is a lot of resentment, and it has been growing in intensity over the past few weeks.

The problem is that Brussels, as we have seen in the recent speech of Jean-Claude Juncker, is more and more inclined to take major decisions without consulting the majority of European states and primarily with the great powers, such as Germany.
That's happening amid growing support for anti-immigration and anti-establishment parties that are also eurosceptic across the continent.
It means the negative-charged emotional climate has reached higher levels than ever before.
This is the conclusion the Financial Times reaches when evaluating the chances of Brexit.
The pro-EU option is based on a cold calculation based on the national interest.
If voters decide it with their brains, the UK will remain in the EU.
But Corbyn's victory reminds us of the power of emotion in modern politics.
Besides, Eastern Europe can be significantly affected by such major developments.
Especially if, as expected, we will see a further integration of the Eurozone, which will push most countries in the region to the periphery of both interest and decision-making process in Europe.
Corbyn, Tsipras and Syriza in Greece, Podemos in Spain, even Bernie Sanders in the United States are all feeding populist rhetoric from the frustrations accumulated in Western societies.
Due to economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity they have enjoyed for the last decades, the generous social benefits, cannot continue in the same way in the following years.

Under the dual pressure of the Eurozone crisis and the immigration crisis, both caused by hasty decisions that took into account only the integrationist political ambitions, not the ability and willingness of the peoples and governments of Europe to respond to such challenges, the turbulence on the continent, the internal tensions within the EU will increase in intensity and can affect majorly the situation in Romania.
And it’s hard to exclude anything from the standpoint of possible scenarios.
The question is whether our main political leaders are capable of dealing with such complicated situations.
Constantin Brancusi, The God of Peasants
Rockefeller: "How can I help you?"
Brancusi: "Go and sweep the workshop!"
The great sculptor had a big dream: to be somebody, to become famous, to be heard about in all over the world.
But behind that renown was something almost forgotten today, when we are delivered millions of success stories, recipes for success in life.
That something has a name.
It's called "trudă".
What to write about Constantin Brâncuși?
What else is there to say?
His image appeared on banknotes.
And, recently, a well known bank in Romania hired an actor to play him in a commercial.
Brâncuși is still producing and shipping money, almost 60 years after his death.
There are hundreds of streets and highways in Romania named after him.
The author of this article lives on one of those streets.
And when she goes out with the child, she hears the following instructions: "We're going to the park, to Brâncuși".
The country is dotted with his statues.
There are few Romanian personalities whose works are known by so many people, from children to the elderly.
Brancusi's infiltration capacity is huge.
The communists have not succeeded in eradicating him from the Romanian memory and culture.
His quotes are now going viral on the internet, receiving hundreds of thousands of likes and shares.
And then, again, what is there to say, to write about this man?
Seen from the heap of books and articles that try to reconstitute his destiny, Brâncuși's life appears almost fantastic, totally improbable.
You know, those people who tell you that if you weren't lucky enough to be born in a big city from a pretty well-off family, your chances of success in life are slim to none.
Brancusi's life is the perfect contrary example.
And maybe here is a key.
Maybe the following text should start from here.
With a sentence, as detestable as it is.
Forget the stupid success stories that are served to you daily in newspapers and on the TV.
Look carefully at this man's face.
Would you like to know how he succeeded in life and how today the whole world knows about him?
It's simple.
She worked all her life to be someone.
It did.
Constantin Brâncuși was born on February 19, 1876, in Hobița, a tiny village in the commune of Peștișani, Gorj county, at the foothills of the Carpathians.
He is the fifth child of Maria and Radu Nicolae Brâncuși.
Although he came from a wealthy peasant family, Brâncuși led a modest life, but one from which he would gather the landmarks that guided his late artistic vision.
In a meeting with Petre Țuțea in Paris in 1933, the artist would recall his childhood and the places he grew up in: "At that time life was beautiful and harmonious."
For millennia, people were happy living patriarchal lives.
Everything went from one season to another.
And do you know why things changed?
The Great City Civilization has reached us.
Brâncuşi's childhood was however far from idyllic.
One of the events of these early years is extremely suggestive for the combination of purity and violence that characterized the future sculptor's years spent in his native place.
The moment is reproduced in the work "Brâncuși. A Biography", written by Alexandru Buican.
In 1879, Constantin Brâncuși was 3 years old.
In the autumn of that year, when things were kept "at the cauldron", watching the tasters to see if the process was going correctly, Brâncuși caught a moment of general inattention.
He fills his palms with plum brandy and drinks it in one gulp.
He falls asleep almost instantly.
The first people notice only after a few minutes.
The mother goes into panic, then hysteria, believing her son has died.
In the evening, when father Radu returns from the vineyard, accompanied by musicians, he sees the desperate signs of those who are waiting for him with bated breath.
The party turns immediately into mourning.
The father is already thinking about the funeral.
Yet someone thinks it is nice to call her Baba Brândușa, witch and servant of Brâncuși.
Brândușa checks the child's breathing and then puts horse dung under his nose, which she collected nearby.
The child sneezes strongly.
World Applauds.
While the boy is left to sleep off his drunkenness, the gypsy party continues with even more force.
The next day, the father and son meet through the orchard.
Radu Brancusi orders Constantin to gather some pieces of rope and bring them to him.
Father puts the child upside down, and with the switches brought by the boy, he beats him in order to remember.
And, as he feels the sting of the blows, the young Brancusi has a revelation that the world can be viewed from another perspective and that things around him can appear upside down.
Especially the fact that the sun is in a different position than the one he knows makes him wonder, as he would confess in his old age, if maybe the star itself was involved in his confusion.
Had the sun been as troubled as his father at what had happened to him?
The city is not working at the moment.
A lawmaker calls on politicians to remember who voted for them.
Independent lawmaker Viorel Blajut appealed to the PNL and PSD to stop their internal bickering and to focus their agenda on the electorate.
What we are seeing on our political stage is a big divide, and nothing else.
I have not seen anything in the USL's 2012 projects that continues.
No highway, no regional emergency hospital, just politicians fighting over possible locations in accordance with real estate interests.
Let's put politics aside for a moment, get together and talk.
The city does not work now.
"If you are busy with the internal war, you have no time for your voters", says Blajut.

He said that the current political class has disappointed the Iasi electorate, the consequence being a very low turnout (around 30 percent) at the next local election, which would represent the loyal electorate of the parties.
The MP also believes the voters will turn to the traditional parties and show reservation about new political initiatives such as the "Pentru Iași" Party which will be launched today.
Local parties have very little chance and will only break up the right-wing electorate, not PSD's.
Such parties rely on active civic people who typically are on the right.
"The right wing is further disintegrating, which is not good for anyone, not even for the PSD," Blajut said.
He said he’s not interested in running for office in the upcoming local elections, dismissing rumors that he plans to enter the race for city hall.
I have said I do not want to run for any local post.
I'm still thinking whether to stay on as a lawmaker in the next term.
I've tried to appeal for unity for Iași and in discussions on the sidelines and I've been accused of making a point of it.
I don't want to, but we can't go on this way.

"If people have voted for us, it doesn't mean they're stupid and won't vote for us if they see nothing", Blajut said and added that the main reason for which the electorate is no longer interested in politics is the hypocrisy of the elected.
A colleague from Tătărași said that he doesn't have enough money and he has to go by bus.
Let's not be hypocrites.
The amount of money involved is not small.
Sometimes I'm ashamed to take money at the cashier.
At the end of the term I shall make a report on the spending of the cabinet, apart from the salaries of the employees and the maintenance.
I happened to raise 30,000 lei in one month, with all the receipts for transport, accommodation and so on.
"It's pure hypocrisy for a lawmaker to say they don't have enough money," Blăjuț concluded.
